name: Alexander Cocktail No. 2
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into cocktail glass. Sprinkle nutmeg on top.
notes: The Alexander #2, also known as the Brandy Alexander, is a darker, richer variation on the original Alexander cocktail, which called for gin instead of cognac. According to historian Barry Popik, this recipe likely made its debut at Rector's, which was New York's premier lobster palace before the Prohibition era. A bartender there named Troy Alexander invented this drink as a tribute to the white-clad Phoebe Snow, a fictitious personage used by the Delaware, Lackawanna, and Western Railroad companies to market a clean-burning variety of coal called anthracite. Don't be afraid to ask the bartender to go easy on the sweet stuff here. Cognac, being sweeter than gin, doesn't need as much support from the crème de cacao.

name: Bamboo Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass.
notes: Louis Eppinger of the Grand Hotel in Yokohama, Japan created the Bamboo as a quaff for visiting dignitaries. Eppinger enjoyed great success both in mixing drinks and in overseeing culinary menus during his time in Japan. Think of this drink as a sherry-based variation on the Martini. The original recipe calls only for dry vermouth, but many people like to incorporate both dry and sweet vermouth to render it a little more approachable. The combination of rich, spicy Angostura bitters with bright, fruity orange bitters will impart a unique and complex flavor profile not found in most cocktails. Given its drier character, it makes a superb apéritif, and is best drunk before a meal.

name: Bijou Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Named after the French word for "jewel" this refreshingly herbal cocktail can be just that when Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is used. This drink requires a quality gin with citrus, and floral botanicals to brighten the cocktail, while also highlighting the interesting flavors of the Campari, and Chartreuse.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass. Add a cherry on top.
notes: One of the earliest known mentions of this late 19th century cocktail is in Harry Johnson's 1882 Bartender's Manual. Bijou is French for jewel and was supposedly named because the colors of the three ingredients—gin, vermouth, and Chartreuse—resembled diamonds, rubies, and emeralds. This drink is packed with big, bold flavors typical of the pre-Prohibition era, but eventually fell out of popularity as American palates drifted toward simpler flavors. The original recipe, which calls for equal parts of the three ingredients, is wildly herbaceous in the most delicious of ways. If it's a little over the top for you, just ask your bartender to please dial back the Chartreuse and vermouth. This will yield a drier, more approachable flavor profile. If you're making your own, remember that dilution is key with a cocktail of this strength.

name: Blinker
instructions: Shake in ice and strain into 8 oz. stem glass. Serve with large piece of ice.
notes: According to David Embury in the 1930s, this drink was “one of a few cocktails using grapefruit juice. Not particularly good, but not too bad.” We respectfully disagree. This cocktail, first published in 1934 in Patrick Gavin Duffy's The Official Mixer's Manual, is a perfect balance of tart citrus and a sweet syrup, rounded out by a spicy rye. A great way to really savor the taste of the whiskey even if you're not in a neat or on-the-rocks kind of mood. The Blinker is an excellent choice for a winter cocktail, especially since everyone knows that grapefruit juice is good for fighting off a cold. If you're looking for variation, try substituting a quality raspberry syrup for the grenadine.

name: Blood and Sand
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Blood and Sand cocktail calls for a smooth scotch with delicate smokiness to pair with the fruit juice and cherry heering. Glenfarclas 10 year is a excellent choice, with it's light smokiness, and delicate aromas of dried fruit and spice, bonds brilliantly with the ingredients to create a balanced cocktail that non scotch drinkers can enjoy.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The Blood and Sand is one of only a few classic concoctions that use Scotch as a base. When made with a softer blend or single-malt, it's a great first step for Scotch skeptics. This cocktail takes its name from the 1922 Rudolph Valentino film by the same name; though some people also attribute the name to the colors of the ingredients. The Blood and Sand first appeared in print in 1930 in Harry Craddock's The Savoy Cocktail Book. The complex balance of smoky and fruity flavors at play in this drink is actually relatively flexible and can be adapted to the taste of the drinker by varying ingredients. For something a little bolder, try a smoky Islay Scotch instead. The flavors pair surprisingly well.

name: Blue Blazer
instructions: Use two large silver-plated mugs, with handles. Put the whiskey into one mug, and the boiling water into the other, ignite the Whiskey, and while blazing mix both ingredients by pouring them four or five times from one mug to the other. If well done, this will have the appearance of a continued stream of liquid fire. Sweeten with 1 Teaspoonful of Powdered White Sugar, and serve with a piece of Lemon Peel. Use 4 oz. Hot Whiskey glass.

name: Blue Blazer
instructions:

name: Blue Blazer

name: Blue Blazer
instructions: Use two large silver-plated mugs with handles. Put the whiskey into one mug and the boiling water into the other. Ignite the whiskey and, while it is blazing, mix both ingredients by pouring them four or five times from one mug to the other. If done well, this will have the appearance of a continuous stream of liquid fire. Sweeten with powdered sugar and serve with a twist of lemon peel. Serve in 4-oz. punch cup.

name: Blue Blazer
instructions:
Warm two large, silver-plated mugs with handles with boiling water; pour out water. Put whiskey into one mug and fresh boiling water
into other mug. Ignite whiskey. While whiskey flames, pour into mug with boiling water. Repeat pouring from one mug into the other,
extending stream to a foot or so. If done well, this will have the appearance of a continuous stream of liquid fire. Sweeten with syrup. Pour into preheated Irish coffee glass and add lemon twist.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions: Stir gently. Place large block of ice in punch bowl. Decorate with fruit in season.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 Dozen Lemons 
Add enough Powdered Sugar to sweeten 
Place large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. 
Then add: 
1 qt. Old Mr. Boston California Brandy
1 qt. Sherry Wine
1/4 pt. Maraschino
1/4 pt. Old Mr. Boston Curacao
4 qts. Champagne
2 qts. Carbonated Water

Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 Dozen Lemons 
Add  enough powdered  sugar  to sweeten. Place large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Then add above ingredients.

Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. Punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice one dozen lemons. Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten. Place large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Then add rest of the ingredients.
Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. Punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 Dozen Lemons

1 qt. Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy
1 qt. Sherry Wine
1/4 pt. Maraschino
1/4 pt. Curacao
4 qts. Champagne
2 qts. Carbonated Water
Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. Punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions: Juice 12 lemons, add enough powdered sugar to sweeten the lemon juice. Pour over a large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Add remaining ingredients, stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice 12 Lemons 
Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten the lemon juice. Pour over a large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Then add: 
1 qt. Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy
1 qt. Dry Sherry
1/2 cup Maraschino 
1/2 cup Old Mr. Boston Triple Sec 
4 bottles Chilled Champagne
2 qts. Chilled Carbonated Water 
Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch

name: Bombay Punch
instructions:
Juice of 12 Lemons 
Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten. Pour over a large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Then add:
32 oz. Brandy
32 oz. Dry Sherry
1/2 cup Maraschino
1/2 cup Triple Sec
4 750-ml bottles Chilled Champagne 
64 oz. Chilled Carbonated Water 
Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in punch glasses.

name: Bombay Punch
instructions: Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten lemon juice. Pour over a large block of ice in punch bowl and stir. Then add remaining ingredients. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in punch cups. Makes 60 servings.

name: Brandy Cobbler
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy's smooth buttery aroma along with flavors of rich fruits make it a great choice for the classic brandy cobbler. Notes of orange peel, apricots and vanilla are accentuated by the tart alcohol that leaves a crisp balanced finish to this classic cocktail.
instructions:
Combine brandy, syrup, and soda water in red-wine glass. Fill glass
with shaved ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve with straws.
notes: According to Jerry Thomas circa 1862, a cobbler—a class of drink all its own—is a simply a spirit or wine sweetened with sugar and fresh fruit, and served over ice. Most early versions used wine as a base spirit, but eventually cobblers of all different sorts began cropping up in American bars. Dale DeGroff is generally credited with standardizing the additional step of muddling the fruits and spirits, making for an exceptionally fresh-tasting drink. These cocktails are fairly flexible as far as ingredients go, so always opt for something seasonal. The Fruit is largely responsible for the flavor here, so the riper, the better. Mr. Thomas actually calls for a whopping four ounces in base spirit in his cobbler recipe, but most people knock it down an ounce or two if only for the pleasure of enjoying more than one.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Brandy Daisy
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: It's smooth fruit flavor and buttery aromatics enhance the rich raspberry notes of the Brandy Daisy, while its crisp balanced finish cuts the tart lemon, producing a sweet balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into beer mug or 8-oz. metal cup. Add ice.
Garnish with fruit.
notes: The Daisy is another one of those categories of drinks that have fallen out of the general public's pool of knowledge over the last century or so. Like cobblers, flips, and other classes of drinks, the Daisy itself is fairly flexible when it comes to ingredients. One of the earliest recorded Daisy recipes is Jerry Thomas's Brandy Daisy, dating back to 1862. Unlike most standard recipes at the time, his called for Curaçao and a few drops of Jamaican rum, one of Brandy's closest spirit companions. Most other classic recipes tend to favor grenadine or raspberry syrup over Curaçao and omit the rum. In our version, raspberry marries beautifully with lemon, making this cocktail the perfect drink to sip on a sunny afternoon on the porch.

name: Brandy Julep
instructions: Put 12 sprigs of fresh mint into a bowl and cover with powdered sugar. Add just enough water to dissolve the sugar and then muddle well. Place half the crushed mint and liquid into a Tom Collins glass. Fill glass half full of shaved ice and then add rest of crushed mint and fill the glass with shaved ice. Add Old Mr. Boston Apricot Nectar and place in a refrigerator for about 30 minutes. Before serving. decorate with sprigs of mint covered with powdered sugar. Serve with a straw.

name: Brandy Julep
instructions:
Put ingredients into 12 oz. Tom Collins glass.

Then fill glass with finely shaved ice, and stir until mint rises to top, being careful not to bruise mint. (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) Decorate with slice of Pineapple, orange, lemon and a cherry. Serve with straws.

name: Cardinal Punch
instructions: Use punch bowl with a large block of ice. Garnish with fruit in season.

name: Cardinal Punch
instructions:
Add enough Powdered Sugar to sweeten.

Place large block of Ice in Punch Bowl and stir well. Then add:
2 qts. Claret
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston California Brandy
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum
1 pt. Champagne 
1/2 pt. Italian Vermouth

Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. punch glasses.

name: Cardinal Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 Dozen Lemons
Add enough Powdered Sugar to sweeten. Place large block of ice in punch bowl and stir well. Then add: 
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy 
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum
1 pt. Champagne
2 qts. Claret
1 qt. Carbonated Water 
1/2 pt. Sweet Vermouth 
Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. punch glasses.

name: Champagne Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Consider world-famous Peychaud’s Bitters instead of Angostura bitters in this cocktail. The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Place sugar and bitters in champagne flute and fill with Champagne.
Add lemon twist.
notes: For those of you who enjoy hosting guests, this cocktail might just be your new favorite. Champagne Cocktails are classy, simple, and definite crowd-pleasers. Perfect for a DIY cocktail station if you're throwing a party. Interestingly enough, in the first edition Jerry Thomas's How to Mix Drinks, published in 1862, the instructions call for all ingredients to be shaken, including the champagne. A later edition of the same book rectified the mistake and altered the instructions, but who knows how many champagne catastrophes occurred in the meantime? Other versions of this drink also include a healthy dose of brandy, but those tend to be a bit heavier on the palate. If you're looking for a little variation, take advantage of the plentiful selection of aromatic bitters at your local spirit shop.

name: Champs Elysees Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Meukow's rich aromas of spice and fruit combined with its round medium body are the perfect pairing for the elegantly herbal Champs Elysees. It's dry-yet fruity flavor bond with the sweet citrus to create a deliciously balanced cocktail with a warm herbaceous finish.

Also consider world-famous Peychaud’s Bitters in this cocktail. A proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices with a flavor profile that is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: No one does elegance quite like the French, and this cocktail is no exception. You've likely heard of the Champs Elysées in Paris, the long, illustrious avenue stretching all the way from the Louvre to the Arc de Triomphe and on to the Défense at the western edge of the city. The name, which is an allusion to Greek mythology, translates to Elysian Fields. This was the place where righteous souls were believed to go after death to continue living blessed and happy lives, and hopefully drinking these. This heavenly concoction seems to have first appeared the Harry Craddock's 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book, though little else is known about it's history. The Champs Elysées is earthy and distinctly aromatic without being overly herbaceous, and it makes an exquisite after-dinner drink. All things considered, this cocktail is très très chic.

name: Country Club Cooler
instructions:
Use 12 oz. Tom Collins glass 

Fill with Ice then Carbonated Water or Ginger Ale

Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Country Club Cooler
instructions:
Into 12 oz. Tom Collins glass, put: 
1/2 Teaspoon Grenadine 
2 oz. Carbonated Water and stir. 
Fill glass with cracked ice and add: 
2 oz. Dry Vermouth 
Fill with carbonated water or ginger ale and stir again. Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Damn-The-Weather Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin and its spicy botanicals give a layer of interest and depth to this fruit forward cocktail, while it's bright citrus aromas add balance and finish the cocktail crisp.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: No one likes being cooped up in the house during a snowstorm—or a polar vortex, as the weathermen seem to be calling it these days. That is unless you happen to have all the ingredients on hand to mix up one of these little wintry potions. First cited in the Savoy Cocktail Book in 1930, Damn the Weather is a typical Prohibition style cocktail, complementing gin with vermouth and citrus and rounding the whole thing off with a little bit of triple sec. Orange is the dominant flavor here, but the vermouth adds a certain earthy and herbal note which is accented by the gin. Like many cocktails from the Prohibition era, Damn the Weather contains more than just a little bit of alcohol, but that's alright. You weren't planning on going anywhere anyway, were you?

name: French "75"
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is a light, smooth, elegant gin with the traditional botanicals of a London Dry that perfect compliment the ingredients of a French 75. It's fresh aromatics of rose, juniper and cucumber and bright citrus make it an excellent gin choice for this bubbly classic.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into chilled champagne
flute and top with Champagne.
notes: The French 75 is a nod to the 75-millimeter M1897, which was the bread and butter of the French military during World War One. Widely regarded as the first modern piece of artillery, these canons could wreak havoc on a large scale in a very short period of time. The same can be said for this cocktail – especially some of the older recipes, which really pour on the gin. Some older versions also strain the base mixture into a Collins glass over cracked ice before adding the champagne, but opting for a flute with no ice will keep it from getting too watered down. This cocktail is a great blend of floral and herbaceous gin with bright, citrusy lemon, and stays pretty light on the palate. If you're looking for a richer, darker flavor profile, try using brandy or cognac in place of the gin.

name: Gin Buck
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The spicy herbal aromas of Fleischmann's Gin along with its sweet lemon flavors are showcased perfectly with the addition of refreshingly spicy ginger ale, making in an excellent choice for the Gin Buck.
instructions:
Pour gin and lemon juice into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Fill
with ginger ale and stir.
notes: The buck is yet another category of drinks lost to the ages. When a base spirit is mixed with ginger ale and citrus, the result is a Buck. Sounds simple, doesn't it? That's because it is. Like many simpler recipes, this one can be easily played with to cater to different tastes. Different base spirits can be substituted to yield different kinds of Bucks, a dash of your favorite liqueur can be added for some extra zing, or ginger beer can be used in place of ginger ale for hardcore ginger fans. Although this cocktail has disappeared from most contemporary cocktail menus, it is the predecessor to many of today's favorites, including the Moscow Mule, which introduced vodka to the American market in the middle of the 20th century. Sure, there are plenty of more complicated drinks out there, but like Leonardo Da Vinci said, simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.

name: Harlem Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The candied lemon and herbal juniper aromas enhance the sweet refreshing flavors of the pineapple juice in the Harlem Cocktail, while the interestingly fruity and peppery finish cut the sugar and highlight the maraschino liqueur, making a balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
pineapple chunks on rim of glass.
notes: The Harlem cocktail is a bit of an enigma. It is clearly one of New York's neighborhood keepsakes, as it bears the name of one of its five boroughs—much like the Manhattan. Unfortunately, little is known about its history though. Speculation has linked the Harlem to a few different cocktails, but no one really knows for sure where it comes from. It is almost reminiscent of a pre-Prohibition style cocktail, except that it calls for pineapple instead of citrus. In any case, the Harlem has an extraordinary flavor profile. Gin lends its herbs and botanicals, maraschino imparts its red-fruity goodness, and pineapple tops it all off with just a kiss of tropical flavor. If you're looking to break out of the ordinary, the Harlem is definitely for you.

name: Income Tax Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
The Income Tax cocktail calls for a London Dry gin to add aromatics and botanicals to the citrus sweetened gin cocktail. Sunset Hill's Small Batch Gin is a great choice, with its citrus forward flavor, but bright aromatics of juniper, cucumber, and rose to tie in the vermouth and produce a balanced cocktail.

Consider Peychaud’s Bitters in place of Angostura bitters in this cocktail. Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Income taxes—the thought alone is reason enough for a cocktail. Whether you're celebrating a hefty return, agonizing over what you owe, or an accountant who's just glad tax season is finally over, this is a great cocktail to take the edge off everyone's least favorite time of year. The Income Tax Cocktail dates back to sometime in the 1920s, when gin, vermouth, and orange juice were the skeleton of many a recipe. The addition of bitters is thought by many to be a nod to the bitterness of giving away a portion of one's hard-earned money to the government. Otherwise, rather befittingly, the history of this cocktail is largely no-nonsense. In any case, this is a drink that goes down well year-round.

notes: The Jack Rose is a history lesson in itself—a veritable “blast from the past”, if you will. This drink was originally made with applejack, a uniquely North American high-proof brandy, which was essentially made by distilling apple cider. As applejack has gone down in popularity, the Jack Rose has become an increasingly rare find, but it is definitely worth tasting. As David Embury put it in his 1948 The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks, it is a deceptively simple cocktail that can “whet rather than dull the appetite”. It's light, aromatic, and makes a perfect autumn cocktail. Embury also included The Jack Rose in the same book as one of the six basic cocktails. Isn't history fun?

name: Kentucky Mint Julep
instructions:
Put 12 sprigs of fresh mint into a 
bowl and cover with powdered sugar. 
Add just enough water to 
dissolve the sugar and then muddle 
well. Place half the crushed mint 
and liquid into a Tom Collins glass. 
Fill glass half full of shaved ice and 
then add rest of crushed mint and 
fill the glass with shaved ice. Add 
Old Mr. Boston Whiskey and place 
in a refrigerator for about 30 minutes. 
Before serving decorate with 
sprigs of mint covered with powdered 
sugar. Serve with a straw.

notes: The term “Knickerbocker” may be a bit unfamiliar to anyone who isn't from the Northeast. Historically speaking, New Yorkers come in 2 main varieties: Yankees and Knickerbockers. Yankees were the Puritan, Sabbath-keeping New Yorkers who liked to go to bed early and refrain from worldly pleasures. Knickerbockers were the antithesis of that. It's fitting really that there should be a cocktail named after them. The Knickerbocker Special is another great summer drink with a much more lush flavor profile than most other rum-based cocktails.  The grenadine provides a much darker taste and balances out the citrus, which tends to dominate in many drink recipes. If you really want to channel the Knickerbockers, try replacing the grenadine with raspberry syrup for an old school twist.

name: Manhattan
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
The traditional Manhattan calls for rye whiskey, and Sazerac Rye provides a much more fuller flavor for this cocktail.  The flavors of candied spices and citrus bond perfectly to the sweet vermouth while the subtle hints of liquorice add an extra depth of flavor to the cocktail.

Consider world-famous Peychaud’s Bitters in the Manhattan cocktail. Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cherry.
notes: The Manhattan is undoubtedly an object of reverence in the cocktail world. According to David Wondrich, it is the only cocktail that can stand up to the Martini. The balance is just so impeccable. It is intense and relaxing at the same time, but, as with many other cocktails, the key is in proper building. The Manhattan has spawned countless variants. Virtually any modification on the ingredients yields a whole new cocktail. Its origins remain somewhat of a mystery. Popular lore suggests that the Manhattan was created by Dr. Iain Marshall at an event hosted by Lady Randolph Churchill—yes, Winston's mother—in honor of presidential candidate Samuel J. Tilden. However, given that Lady Churchill was both in France and pregnant at the time, the story is likely nothing but a myth. Whatever the origins of this cocktail, it is undeniably a sip of history.

name: Manhattan Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
cherry.
notes:
A hundred years after the Old-Fashioned, near the end of the 1800s, we find the Manhattan. In the second half of the 1800s cocktails began to really catch on, and bartenders were expanding both their repertoire of drinks and the palette of products at their disposal for making them.
Simplicity of design, however, was still very much at the core of all
drinks. The Manhattan appears to have come onto the scene about 1882, at which time it was mentioned that a cocktail made from just whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters was coming into vogue. It went by not only "Manhattan", but also "Turf Club Cocktail" and "Jockey Club Cocktail". The "Manhattan" moniker almost certainly comes from the Manhattan
Club of New York, with the other clubs eager to have their names
attached to the drink as well.

name: Martinez Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This strong but balanced cocktail calls for a gin with fresh floral aromatics along, and light sweetness to balance the vermouth. Sunset Hill's blend of cucumber, juniper, and rose make it an excellent choice for the Martinez.
instructions:
Shake up thoroughly, and strain into a large cocktail glass. Put a
quarter of a slice of lemon in the glass and serve. If the guest prefers
it very sweet, add two dashes of gum syrup.
notes: The Martinez is a tricky cocktail to pin down. Even in its earliest mention in 1884, the author provides not one, but two different recipes for this tasty tipple. Although many people consider it to be the missing evolutionary link between the Manhattan and the Martini, lots of people don't even know it exists. So what keeps the Martinez going? A lot actually. First of all, the Martinez is actually the predecessor to the Martini, which is widely considered the greatest cocktail ever to be poured. The Martinez plays to a much older style though. Where the Martini is dry and crisp, the Martinez is lush and round with rich spice notes to balance everything out. Like many truly classic cocktails, everyone likes to drink their Martinez a specific way, so feel free to play around until you find yours.

notes: Milk Punch is a famed cocktail throughout the South, especially at Christmas time. It's one of the few drinks that are sure to bring out that warm, cozy feeling even though they're best served chilled. This cocktail isn't just a source of Yuletide cheer though. New Orleanians often drink it for brunch year-round, and it can be particularly refreshing after the occasional indulgent evening. In Colonial America, milk and brandy were thought to have strong medicinal properties. This tasty elixir grew quickly in popularity, and eventually people started drinking it for pleasure rather than for health—and who can blame them? Milk punch is like homemade ice cream, but better. If you have the supplies, opt for freshly grated spices. You will taste the difference.

name: Mint Julep
instructions: Put about 4 sprigs of mint into tumbler. Add teaspoonful water. Then muddle well. Fill mixing glass with ice. Add 1 Jigger Old Mr. Boston Whiskey. Stir well and top with dash of Rum. Garnish with fruit and mint. Sprinkle mint with powdered sugar. Serve in Tom Collins glass.

name: Mint Julep
instructions:
Muddle above ingredients into Silver Mug or 12 oz. Tom Collins glass. 

Fill glass or mug with shaved ice, add 2 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Straight Bourbon Whiskey, and stir gently until glass is frosted.

Decorate with slice of orange, lemon, pineapple and a cherry. Insert 5 or 6 sprigs of mint on top. Serve with straws.

name: Mint Julep
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: No drink out there says southern culture quite like the mint julep.  This very old very traditional concoction, dates back to before The Kentucky Derby where it's the official drink.  Being such an old potable, W L Weller with it's long history as a proper Kentucky Bourbon, is a perfect fit.  The wheated recipe bring a wonderful mellow flavor to the drink, and as it melts, the drink transforms into something reminiscent of mint sweet tea.
instructions: Pour syrup into silver julep cup, silver mug, or Collins glass. Fill with shaved or crushed ice and add bourbon. Stir until glass is heavily frosted, adding more ice if necessary. (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) Garnish with mint so that the tops are about 2 inches above rim of glass. Use short straws so that it will be necessary to bury nose in mint, which is intended for scent rather than taste.
notes: The Mint Julep has been the official drink of the Kentucky Derby for almost a century now, and the fastest two minutes in sports just wouldn't feel right without a frosted silver cup in one hand. The origins of this drink predate the Derby by several centuries though. Like many of its cousins, the Julep was originally drunk for medicinal purposes. The name comes from the Arabic word julab and the Persian word gulab, which both translate to “rosewater”. In the early days of America, people made juleps with a number of spirits including rum and brandy, but history seems to suggest that the original julep was actually made with cognac. At the time, bourbon was reserved mostly for poor southerners who couldn't afford fine liquor. My how the proverbial tables have turned. Next time you're in bourbon country, be sure to try one of these classic southern libations.

name: New York Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Because Buffalo Trace has large depth of flavor it is truly a go to whiskey for cocktails, but is exceptional in a New York Sour.  The soft dark fruit qualities in Buffalo Trace, bond brilliantly with the addition of port found in this cocktail, thus creating a superbly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled oldfashioned
glass. Float red wine on top. Garnish with lemon and
cherry.
notes: The New York Sour has gone by many names. Most people believe that it actually originated in Chicago, where it was called a Continental Sour, then made its way south, where it was called a Southern Whiskey Sour, before finally making its way up the East Coast into New York. Whatever you call it, it's an absolutely delicious—not to mention gorgeous—drink. If you can make a whiskey sour, you've already got the bulk of the technique needed for this tasty tipple. You can omit the egg if you like, but doing so will reduce the body and texture of the drink. Floating the red wine is simple enough. All you need is the back of a spoon and a steady pour. This drink is sure to impress whiskey and wine-lovers alike. Plus layering drinks is an impressive party trick.

name: Old Fashioned Cocktail
instructions:
Use Old Fashioned cocktail glass.
1/2 Lump of Sugar
2 Dashes Bitters
Add enough water to cover sugar and muddle well.
1 Cube of Ice
2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Whiskey* 
Stir well. Add twist of lemon rind and drop in glass. Decorate with slice of orange, lemon and a cherry. Serve with stirring rod.

name: Old Fashioned Cocktail
instructions: Into an old-fashioned glass put a small cube of sugar, a dash of Angostura bitters, a teaspoon of water and muddle well. Add 2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Blended Whiskey. Stir. Add twist of lemon peel and ice cubes. Decorate with slice of orange, lemon, and a cherry. Serve with a swizzle stick.

name: Old-Fashioned
instructions: In old-fashioned glass, put sugar cube, bitters, and water and muddle well. Add whiskey, stir. Add a twist of lemon peel and ice cubes. Decorate with slices of orange and lemon and a cherry. Serve with a swizzle stick.

name: Old-Fashioned Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Blanton's Bourbon with its dry vanilla notes and hints of nutmeg, is an excellent choice for the Old Fashioned. The old fashioned and its ingredients are made to highlight the base spirit so using Blanton's, a premium spirit will give you the highest quality cocktail.
instructions: Pour whiskey, syrup, and bitters into cracked ice-filled old-fashioned glass and stir. Garnish with orange and cherry.
notes: Some people say that history is a matter of perspective. The history of the Old Fashioned is precisely that. “Old Fashioned” is thought by many to have originally been applicable to any drink. It would have been like ordering a cocktail “the old-fashioned way”, which probably varied about as much as house rules in a game of Monopoly. In any case, the cocktail we now know as the Old Fashioned is said to have originated at the Pendennis Club in Louisville, Kentucky. Mixing drinks in the heart of bourbon country, it seems likely that the bartender would have used bourbon, but the Old Fashioned is also commonly made with rye whiskey for a drier and lighter cocktail. Several recipes call for muddled fruit and soda water, and there's nothing wrong with that per se. We prefer the more basic method though, as it really brings the whiskey to the foreground.

name: Planter's Punch
instructions: Shake well with cracked ice and strain into a large goblet. Add cube of ice and decorate with fruit.
notes: Planter's Punch has a definite Caribbean feel to it, but its origins are actually disputed. One story says that a Jamaican planter's wife came up the recipe as drink to cool off workers. Another story claims that it was invented at the Planter's Hotel in St. Louis. Either way, this cocktail was first mentioned in print in the New York Times in 1908. Like many other drinks, there are countless variations on Planter's Punch. Many recipes don't even specify what fruit juices are supposed to be used. If you play around with it a bit, you will find that, like most punches, it is a very versatile drink that can work with any number of different flavor combinations. Also in keeping with its punch status, this is a great party drink and is easy to make in large quantities.

name: Remsen Cooler
instructions: Peel rind of Lemon in spiral form, place in long tumbler with cubes of ice, add jigger Old Mr. Boston Dry Gin and fill with soda water. Use l0 oz. glass.

name: Remsen Cooler
instructions:
Into 12 oz. Tom Collins glass, put: 
1/2 Teaspoon  Powdered Sugar 
2 oz. Carbonated Water, and stir
Fill glass with Cracked Ice and add: 
2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Dry Gin
Fill with Carbonated Water or Ginger Ale

Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Remsen Cooler
instructions:
Into 12 oz. Tom Collins glass, put:
1/2 Teaspoon Powdered Sugar
2 oz. Carbonated Water
Stir; fill glass with Cracked Ice and add:
2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Dry Gin
Fill with carbonated water or ginger ale and stir again. Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Remsen Cooler

Fill with carbonated water or ginger ale and stir again. Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Remsen Cooler

name: Rum Cobbler

Fill 10 oz. Goblet with Shaved Ice
Add 2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum

Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve with straws.

name: Rum Cobbler

Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve with straws.

name: Sazerac Cocktail
instructions:
Put 1/4 Teaspoon Absinthe Substitute into an Old Fashioned cocktail glass and revolve glass until it is entirely coated with the Absinthe Substitute. Then add above ingredients.

Stir very well. Add twist of lemon peel.  (For best results, put glass on ice for a few minutes before using.)

name: Sazerac Cocktail
instructions:
Put 1/4 Teaspoon Absinthe Substitute into an Old Fashioned cocktail glass and revolve glass until it is entirely coated with the Absinthe Substitute.
Then add:
1/2 Lump of Sugar
2 Dashes Bitters
Sufficient water to cover sugar, and muddle well.
2 Cubes of Ice
2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Whiskey*
Stir very well. Add twist of lemon
peel. (For best results, put glass on ice for a few minutes before using.)

name: Sazerac Cocktail

name: Sazerac Cocktail
instructions: Put 1/4 teaspoon absinthe substitute into old-fashioned glass until it is entirely coated with the liquid. Then add 1/2 lump of sugar, 2 dashes bitters, and sufficient water to cover sugar, and muddle well. Stir in 2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Blended Whiskey and add two ice cubes and a twist of lemon peel. (For best results, put glass on ice for a few minutes before using.)
notes: It's no surprise that America's first cocktail was created in New Orleans, the original cocktail Mecca. By 1850, the Sazerac was already a wildly popular drink. At the time though, it was made with Sazerac-de-Forge et Fils, a French brandy from which the cocktail drew its name. In 1873, the recipe was altered to call for American whiskey and a dash of absinthe rather than brandy. The reason for this being that European vineyards were under attack by an American aphid called Phylloxera Vastatrix. European wine production plummeted, which, in turn, affected the brandy industry as well. Many people have a strong preference for rye whiskey in a Sazerac, and indeed the official recipe calls for Sazerac Rye. Whatever your spirit preference, this cocktail is undoubtedly an American classic.

name: Sazerac Cocktail
instructions: In an old-fashioned glass, swirl Pernod until inside of glass is completely coated. Mix remaining ingredients in cocktail shaker and strain into coated glass. Add a twist of lemon.

name: Sazerac (Rye)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sazerac Rye is the perfect choice for the Sazerac as it is full of body and spice, but also has a silky buttery quality that allows for a well balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Fill old-fashioned glass with ice. Muddle sugar and bitters in second
old-fashioned glass. Add whiskey and stir. Discard ice from first
glass. Add absinthe to chilled glass, swirl to coat inside, and discard
excess absinthe. Pour whiskey mixture from second glass into chilled
glass. Twist lemon over drink, but do not add to glass.
notes:
The official cocktail of New Orleans, nowadays made with rye. The
original used cognac, which also makes a fine Sazerac.

name: Singapore Sling
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Singapore Sling is a fruity gin cocktail with a little spice found in the Angostura bitters and Benedictine. Fleischmann's gin, with its bright candied lemon flavor and spicy juniper aromas cut the sugary sweetness of the fruit juice, and enhance the interesting spice of the Benedictine, making it an excellent choice for the Singapore Sling.
instructions: Shake lemon, sugar, and gin with ice and strain into collins glass. Add ice cubes and fill with club soda. Float cherry-flavored brandy on top. Decorate with fruits in season and serve with straws.
notes: The Sling was a type of drink typically made with gin that was mixed with a bit of water, flavored, sweetened, and served cold. The Singapore Sling is a variation on this theme that was developed at the turn of the 20th century by Ngiam Tong Boon, a bartender at the Raffles Hotel in Singapore. If you visit the hotel today, you can actually see the safe where Boon stored his cocktail books. The Singapore Sling was taken off the hotel menu at one point and nearly forgotten. When the hotel wanted to revive it some time later, the bartenders had to rack their brains to remember the recipe. As is common with older cocktails, few people agree on how to make this one. Different recipes call for different fruit juices and even different liqueurs. Whatever your school of thought, this is a sweet, complex cocktail that you're sure to love.

name: South-Side Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin freshness and bright aromatics pair harmoniously with the citrus and mint in the Southside cocktail. This summer cocktail is best supported by a light smooth gin with nuanced botanicals instead of a traditional London Dry.
instructions:
Muddle mint leaves gently in mixing glass. Add remaining
ingredients and shake with ice. Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
Add the mint sprig.
notes: There are no less than three competing stories as to how the Southside cocktail came to be. Perhaps the most interesting of them hails from Chicago. In the 1920s, Chicago was a city under violent gang rule. Three bootleggers controlled the city, and a hard line was drawn between North and South Chicago. On the North Side, people drank gin and ginger ale, which, consequently, is called a North Side cocktail. South Side mobsters didn't have as much access to quality liquor and were forced to use stronger flavors to mask the taste of bad gin. The Southside cocktail is an example of one of the most successful recipes for doing just that. There are a couple of fun spins on this cocktail as well. Try adding soda water and serving it over ice for a Southside Fizz, or stick with the coupe and add a healthy dose of champagne for a Southside Royale.

name: Tom and Jerry
instructions: Stir thoroughly while pouring in hot milk and grate Nutmeg on top. Use Tom and Jerry mug.

name: Tom and Jerry
instructions:
First prepare batter, using mixing bowl. Separate the yolk and white of 1 egg, beating each separately and thoroughly. Then combine both, adding enough superfine powdered sugar to stiffen. Add to this 1 pinch of baking soda and 1/4 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum to preserve the batter. Then add a little more sugar to stiffen. To serve, use hot Tom and Jerry mug, using 1 tablespoon of above batter, dissolved in 3 tablespoons hot milk. Add 1 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum. Then fill mug with hot milk within 1/4 inch of top of mug and stir gently. Then top with 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston California Brandy and grate a little nutmeg on top.

The secret of a Tom and Jerry is to have a stiff batter and a warm mug.

Add to this 1 pinch of baking soda and 1/4 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum to preserve the batter. Then add a little more sugar to stiffen. To serve, use hot Tom and Jerry mug, using 1 tablespoon of above batter, dissolved in 3 tablespoons hot milk. Add 1 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum. Then fill mug with hot milk within 1/4 inch of top of mug and stir gently. Then top with 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy and grate a little nutmeg on top.
The secret of a Tom and Jerry is to have a stiff batter and a warm mug.

name: Tom-And-Jerry
instructions: First prepare batter, using mixing bowl. Separate the yolk and white of one egg, beating each separately and thoroughly. Then combine both, adding enough superfine powdered sugar to stiffen. Add to this one pinch of baking soda and 1/4 oz. Old Mr. Boston rum to preserve the batter. Then add a little more sugar to stiffen. To serve, use hot Tom-and-Jerry mug, using one tablespoon of above batter, dissolved in 3 tablespoons hot milk. Add 1 1/2 oz. Old. Mr. Boston Rum. Then fill mug with hot milk within 1/4 inch of the top of he mug and stir. Then top with 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston brandy and sprinkle a little nutmeg on top. The secret of a tom and jerry is to have a stuff batter and warm mug.

To serve, use hot Tom-and-Jerry mug, using one tablespoon of above batter, dissolved in 3 tablespoons hot milk. Add rum. Then fill mug with hot milk within 1/4 inch of the top of the mug and stir. name: Tom-and-Jerry
instructions:
First prepare batter, using yolk and white of one egg, beating each separately and thoroughly. Then combine both, adding enough superfine powdered sugar to stiffen. Add to this one pinch of baking soda and rum to preserve the batter. Then add a little more  sugar to stiffen.
Hot Milk
1 1/2 oz. Light Rum
1/2 oz. Brandy
To serve, use hot mug, using one tablespoon of above batter, dissolved in 3 tablespoons hot milk. Add rum. Then fill mug with hot milk within 1/4 inch of the top of the mug and stir. Then top with brandy and sprinkle a little nutmeg on top. The secret of a Tom-and-Jerry is to have a stiff batter and a warm mug.

name: Tom and Jerry
instructions:
To make batter, beat egg whites and cream of tartar in medium bowl
to stiff peaks. Beat yolks in another medium bowl until slightly
thickened. Gradually beat in 1 cup of the sugar. Mix in rum,
cinnamon, cloves, and allspice. Mix in remaining 1 cup sugar. Fold
in whites. Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve, up to 2 days.
Makes 3½ c. batter, enough for about 28 drinks. For 1 serving, combine brandy and batter in preheated punch cup or
coffee mug. Fill with boiling water and stir well. Top with nutmeg.
notes: The Tom and Jerry is a warm and fuzzy Christmastime cocktail similar to eggnog. The main difference is that this drink is served hot. Although it has been largely forgotten in most parts of the country, the Tom and Jerry has been preserved in both Wisconsin and Minnesota, where, during the holiday season, regional markets even sell pre-made Tom and Jerry batter. The creator of this Yuletide brew was actually an Englishman by the name of Pierce Egan. He came up with the recipe and used it to promote a book he had authored and the subsequent stage play based on it. Contrary to what you might believe, the name is not a reference to MGM's animated cat-and-mouse duo, “Tom and Jerry”. Whether you're familiar with the creator or not, this cocktail is sure to warm you up on a cold winter's night and turn any day into a holiday.

name: Tom Collins
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The candied lemon and herbal juniper aromas enhance the bright refreshing flavors of the Tom Collins, while the fruity and peppery finish cut through the sugar, making a balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake gin, lemon juice, and syrup with ice and strain into Collins
glass. Add several ice cubes, fill with soda water, and stir. Garnish
with orange, lemon, and cherry. Serve with a straw.
notes: At one time, there were a great many Collins drinks out there, and many of them are still floating around today. You may have heard of a John Collins, a Charlie Collins, or others, but the Tom Collins is arguably the most famous. Perhaps this is due to America's past penchant for gin. Whatever the cause, the Tom Collins is one of those timeless mixtures of simple, pure ingredients, coming together to yield a delicious cocktail. According to legend, a waiter named John Collins at Limmer's Old House in London unwittingly lent his name to a popular drink made with Holland gin. From there, someone decided to experiment a little and switched the Holland gin out for Old Tom Gin. The name got changed accordingly, and several others followed suit with their own variations. Whatever the real story is, this is a summer drink that deserves a revival.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset HIll's citrus aromas brighten the herbal qualities of the Tuxedo cocktail, while it's floral botanicals bond brilliantly with the maraschino and vermouth, to create a clean, elegant classic.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add the cherry.
notes: The Tuxedo is certainly a blue-blood drink. It's part of a family of cocktails from the late 18th and early 19th centuries that Jerry Thomas might have referred to as “fancy martinis”—gin, vermouth, bitters, a dash of maraschino, and occasionally a little absinthe. Interestingly enough, in Daly's Bartenders' Encyclopedia from 1903, the Tuxedo recipe calls for Maple Gin, which, apparently, was dry gin sweetened with a drizzle of maple syrup. Apparently Daly was alone in his passion for maple gin, as it doesn't really seem to turn up anywhere else. Over the next several years, the Tuxedo continued to evolve with snapshots being taken from time to time in the form of written recipes. The more eccentric ones included sherry, which yielded an exceptionally dry, nutty cocktail. The maraschino and absinthe do a much better job of balancing the gin and vermouth, so we recommend sticking with them.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sazerac Rye is the perfect choice for the Ward Eight. as it is full of body and spice to cut through the sweetness of the fruit juice, but also has a silky buttery quality that allows for a well interesting and balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into red-wine glass filled with ice. Garnish
with orange, lemon, and cherry. Serve with straws.
notes: The Ward Eight was invented in 1898 by bartender Tom Hussion at the Locke-Ober Café in Boston. Many of his customers were members of a political club called the Hendrick's Club, run by one Martin Lomasney. Lomasney ran for public office that year in Boston's Eighth Ward—now Roxbury and the South End—and one of the club members asked Hussion to create a drink to toast his victory. Hussion obliged and whipped up this little concoction for his patrons. The funny thing is that Lomasney was actually a staunch prohibitionist and would later close the bar that had invented this cocktail in celebration of his victory.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Because Buffalo Trace has large depth of flavor it is truly a go to whiskey for cocktails, but is excellent for a Whiskey Smash.  The citrus and honey qualities in Buffalo Trace, pair brilliantly with the freshly muddled mint, thus creating a superbly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle sugar with soda water and mint in old-fashioned glass. Add
whiskey and then ice cubes. Stir. Garnish with orange and cherry,
and add lemon twist.
notes: Every Smash is a Julep, but not every Julep is a Smash—sort of like that rule about squares and rectangles that you learned in geometry class. We'll spare you all the historical details about what distinguishes the two though. Truth be told, in some cases it's a question of presentation. Smashes, like Sours or Daisies, can be made with any kind of base spirit, but whiskey is generally preferred. This minty cooler makes a great daytime beverage, and is simple enough to whip up even if you've already had a couple. Historically, Smashes included fruit, and many bars will muddle lemon into theirs. This adds a nice citrusy bite to the drink, but also brings it closer to a minty whiskey sour. However you prefer yours, the Whiskey Smash is the perfect libation summer afternoon.

name: Whiskey Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: EH Taylor rye whiskey is a great choice for a whiskey sour because the sharp spice, and bright acidity allows it to blend perfectly with the fruit juice while maintaining its identity. Because EH Taylor uses all rye and no corn in its mash blend, it has a unique dried fruit and pepper taste that brings depth to a simple classic.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
lemon and cherry.
notes: The Sour, like the Gimlet, can be traced back to sailors who drank various spirits with citrus to prevent Scurvy. The practice was brought to land on both sides of the Atlantic, but on the American side, people often preferred native whiskeys to rum and other spirits. Jerry Thomas included a popular recipe in his 1862 book The Bartender's Guide and called it a Sour. Like Smashes and Flips, Sours can be made with any spirit, but whiskey is perhaps most common. Jerry Thomas's recipe did not include egg white, which is a common ingredient nowadays. The egg white was added later for froth and texture. Many recipes call for an optional egg white but don't require it. The truth is that egg doesn't really affect the taste of a drink, but rather the body. However you make it, the Whiskey Sour is a great afternoon or before-dinner drink.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This pleasantly dry cocktail requires a delicate rum with balanced sweetness, making Calypso White Rum and excellent choice from the X, Y, Z cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The XYZ cocktail is about as simple as it gets as far as cocktails go. This simplistic but refreshing recipe is an easy fix if your bar is running low, and you need to entertain. One of the great things about this cocktail is that, with an ingredient list this uncomplicated, you can really experiment with different styles of rum. The actual recipe calls for light rum, which will provide a light, clean flavor profile. But this drink is easy to experiment with. Using different styles of rum will showcase their various flavor profiles. If you're looking to play around with different types of rum but don't necessarily care for rum on its own, this cocktail could prove an invaluable tool for you.

name: American Grog
instructions: Put rum, lemon juice, and sugar cube in preheated Irish coffee glass. Fill with hot water. Stir to dissolve sugar.
notes: Water, water everywhere, and not a drop to drink. Such has always been the obstacle on long sea voyages. Before ships had electricity and refrigeration—in other words, throughout most of history—sailors had to find ways to stay hydrated whilst aboard their ships. Wine and beer quickly turned sour, and water went stale, grew algae, and became slimy. Sometime in the mid-1700s, Vice Admiral Edward Vernon issued an order for rum to be mixed with his ship's water supply to keep it from spoiling. His trick worked, and became standard practice amongst many sailors. The name “Grog” is a nod to Vice Admiral Vernon, who was nicknamed “Old Grog” because of a grogram jacket he often wore. Given his popularity amongst his crew, they dubbed the mixture “Grog” in his honor.

name: Banana Punch
instructions:
Mix 1 1/2 quarts water and sugar in large bowl to dissolve. Add juices
and bananas. Pour into 4 (1-quart) freezer containers and freeze
overnight. About 1 hour before serving, unmold and transfer to large
punch bowl to melt slightly. Stir in club soda. Serve in punch cups.

name: Bloody Mary Cocktail
instructions: Roll with ice between both halves of Boston shaker. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish with lime and olives.
notes: Many cocktails (one might say the majority) have a fruity or sweet/sour element. Yet the beloved Bloody Mary is a fine example of a savory cocktail, zinged with Worcestershire, hot red pepper sauce, and often horseradish.

name: Brandy Swizzle
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir brandy, lime juice, syrup, and bitters in Collins glass. Add ice
and enough soda to fill glass ¾ full. Swizzle with barspoon to frost
glass. Add more ice and soda as needed. Serve with swizzle stick.

name: Christmas Yule Egg Nog
instructions:
Beat the yolks and whites of 1 Dozen Eggs separately and then pour together and add above ingredients and 2 lbs. Granulated Sugar then beat into stiff batter. 

Then add: 
1 qt. Milk
1 qt. Sweet Cream
2 qts. Old Mr. Boston Rye or Bourbon Whiskey and stir. Set in refrigerator over night.

Before serving, stir again, and serve in 4 oz. punch glasses, and grate nutmeg on top.

name: Coffee Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy with its sweet caramel and butterscotch aromatics, combined with its smooth body and light spice from the barrel, create an excellent pairing with the port wine used in the Coffee Cocktail #1.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into sour glass. Sprinkle nutmeg on top.
notes: Decaf drinkers, have no fear. You will find nary a drop of caffeine in this little delight. The Coffee Cocktail seems to have been given its name for two reasons. The first is its café color. The second seems to have something to do with people's penchant to replace after-dinner coffee with an after-dinner inebriant—not that we disapprove. This drink appears to trace all the way back to the 1887 edition of Jerry Thomas's The Bar-Tender's Guide. At a time when the word cocktail invariably indicated the use of bitters, this drink was a misnomer in more ways than one. Still, it grew in popularity and eventually became a classic. The Coffee Cocktail makes a superb after-dinner drink, but can also serve quite well as an apéritif. And for those with a caffeine aversion, it is, of course, caffeine-free.

name: Cuba Libre
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Cuba Libre is a simple, refreshing cocktail with big flavor. Using a rum with a powerful cane sugar flavor gives this highball body, and sweetness. Calypso White Rum has a light body to keep the cocktail refreshing, but a dominant cane sugar flavor to give it a rich sweetness.
instructions:
Pour rum into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with cola and stir.
Squeeze lime into glass and add wedge.
notes: Even if you flunked Spanish 101, you probably already know that Cuba Libre means Free Cuba. This was both a battle cry during the Spanish-American War and a celebratory toast thereafter. Once Cuba had won its independence from Spain, Coca-Cola was sold freely on the Cuban market. It was a commonly mixed with Cuban rum—usually Bacardí—and a squeeze of lime. During the Second World War, American spirits were scarce outside the military, and the only substitute imported in substantial quantities was Caribbean rum. Due to the rationing of sugar, there were few products to mix with alcohol aside from Coca-Cola. Thus, the Cuba Libre surged in popularity. The harsh truth is that after Coca-Cola removed some of its more dubious components in 1903, we'll never know what the original Cuba Libre was like. But that shouldn't stop anyone from toasting “Por Cuba libre!”

name: El Presidente Cocktail No. 1
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Corpse Reviver is all about balancing the bright citrus of the lemon and triple sec, and the herbal notes of the absinthe. The spicy coriander and pine of Fleischmann's Gin along with its citrus and herbal botanicals create a perfect bridge between the other ingredients, finding the balance which is key in the Corpse Reviver No.2
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Like the Corpse Reviver, there are a few different variations on this cocktail, generally denoted by numbers. This particular recipe is essentially a softer, fruitier version of a Daiquiri. The combination of pineapple and rum is, as usual, reminiscent of a beach vacation and helps tone down the acidity of the lime. Grenadine imparts just enough sweetness and a tart pomegranate note for a bit of added depth. Be sure to use real grenadine syrup though, none of that chemical cherry nonsense. This cocktail is among Havana's many contributions to drink menus everywhere and is sure to refresh on even the most sweltering of summer days. Just be careful, these things go down like adult juice boxes.

It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Fish House Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 Dozen Lemons
Add enough Powdered Sugar to sweeten 
1 qt. Carbonated Water
Place large block of Ice in Punch bowl and stir well.
Then add: 
1 1/2 qts. Old Mr. Boston California Brandy 
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston Peach Flavored Brandy 
1 pt. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum

Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. Punch glasses.

 Some prefer to add the strained contents of a pot of tea. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in 4 oz. Punch glasses.

name: Fish House Punch
instructions:
Juice 1 dozen Lemons.

1 1/2 qts. Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy

name: Fish House Punch

name: Fish House Punch
instructions:
Juice of 1 dozen Lemons
Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten. Pour over large block of ice in punch bowl and stir well. Then add:
1 1/2 liters Brandy 
1 liter Peach-Flavored 16 oz. Light Rum 
32 oz. Carbonated Water 
16 oz. Strong Tea (optional)
Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Serve in punch glasses.

name: Fish House Punch
instructions: Add enough powdered sugar to sweeten lemon juice. Pour over large block of ice in punch bowl and stir well. Then add remaining ingredients. Stir well and decorate with fruits in season. Makes 40 servings.

name: Fish House Punch
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Meukow rich fruit and spice flavors make it a excellent choice of cognac for the classic Fish House Punch. It's sweet aromas and flavor pair nicely with the recipe, and hold up to the abundance of ingredients allowing its flavors to shine.
instructions:
Stir in punch bowl. Add large block of ice. Garnish with fruit. Serve
in punch cups
notes: Philadelphia summers are hot. Air conditioning certainly helps, but in the middle of the 1700s, a century and a half before it was invented, alternative cooling methods had to be employed. Enter Fish House Punch. In 1732, Philadelphia saw the founding of the State in Schuylkill Fishing Corporation, a fishing club for some of its elite. They built a clubhouse on the edge the Schuylkill (pronounced “Skookul”) River and fiddled around with punch recipes until they settled on an official one. Apparently, these guys really knew what they were doing. The club is still functional, and their punch is still delicious. Like other punch recipes, this would've originally been mixed up in a substantial quantity in a punch bowl and served to a large group. This stuff is so tasty you might be inclined to drink the whole bowl yourself. Watch out though. This punch is mighty potent.

name: Harvard Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Hollywood Cooler
instructions:

notes: The Horse's Neck was originally a soft drink with iced ginger ale garnished with lots of lemon peel. At some point in its history, an enterprising bartender added bourbon (or brandy) to give it a 'kick.'

Fill with boiling water and stir.

name: Hot Buttered Rum
instructions: Put syrup into preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Fill with boiling water. Add rum and butter and stir. Top with nutmeg.
notes:
Hot buttered rum is perhaps the ultimate chill-chaser. If you don't have Demerara syrup, dissolve 1 tsp. Demerara sugar (or light or dark brown sugar) in the boiling water.

Demerara Syrup: This syrup gives a richer, molasses-like sweetness and an earthy color to cocktails. Substitute 1 c. Demerara sugar for
the granulated sugar. Store in refrigerator for up to 2 months.

name: Hot Buttered Wine
instructions: For each serving—heat 1/2 cup Old Mr. Boston California Muscatel Wine. Add 1/4 cup water just to simmering; do not boil. Preheat mug or cup with boiling water. Pour heated wine mixture into mug and add 1 teaspoon butter and 2 teaspoons maple syrup. Stir  well and sprinkle nutmeg on  top. Serve at once.

Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or   both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

name: Mint Julep (Southern Style)
instructions:
Fill siver mug or 12 oz. Tom Collins glass with finely shaved ice. Add 2 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Bourbon Whiskey and stir until glass is heavily frosted. (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) 

Add 1 teaspoon powdered sugar and fill balance with water, and stir. Decorate with 5 or 6 sprigs of fresh mint so that the tops are about 2 inches above rim of mug or glass. Use short straws so that it is necessary to bury nose in mint. The mint is intended for odor rather than taste.

name: Mint Julep (Southern Style)
instructions:
Fill silver mug or 12 oz. Tom Collins glass with finely shaved ice. Add 2 1/2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Kentucky Straight Bourbon Whiskey and stir until glass is heavily frosted. (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) 

Add 1 teaspoon powdered sugar and fill balance with water, and stir. Decorate with 5 or 6 sprigs of fresh mint so that the tops are about 2 inches above rim of mug or glass. Use short straws so that it is necessary to bury nose in mint. The mint is intended for odor rather than taste.

name: Mint Julep (Southern Style)
instructions: Into a silver mug or 12 oz. Tom Collins glass, dissolve 1 teaspoon powdered sugar with 2 teaspoons of water. Then fill with finely shaved ice and add 2 1/2 ozs. Old Mr. Boston Kentucky Straight Bourbon Whiskey. Stir until glass is heavily frosted adding more ice if necessary, (Do not hold glass with hand while stirring.) Decorate with 5 or 6 sprigs of fresh mint so that the tops are about 2 inches above rim of mug or glass. Use short straws so that it will be necessary to bury nose in mint. The mint is intended for odor rather than taste.

name: Moscow Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the refreshing qualities of a Moscow Mule.  While it's buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the lime, providing a much better balanced drink.
instructions:
Pour vodka and lime juice into copper Moscow Mule mug or
standard beer mug. Add ice cubes and fill with ginger beer. Squeeze
lime wedge and add to glass.
notes: Despite what the flavored vodka craze might make you think, vodka is actually a fairly recent addition to the American liquor market. As recently as the 1930s, Americans hardly even touched the stuff. The Moscow Mule is the cocktail that single-handedly changed that fact forever. John G. Martin bought the rights to Smirnoff vodka for Heublein Spirits in the late 30s. He had a difficult time selling it though, and decided to partner up with Jack Morgan, owner of the British pub Cock ‘n' Bull in Los Angeles, who, incidentally, was having trouble selling off the large stock of ginger beer he had recently purchased. The two collaborated and came up with this simple, yet refreshing recipe, which ignited the vodka craze of the 50s and would later lead bartenders to create every kind of “Mule” imaginable.

instructions: Mix in a collins glass, add ice cubes and stir until glass is frosted. Add two dashes bitters and 2 1/2 oz. Light Rum. Stir and top with a dash of grenadine. Decorate with slices of lemon, orange, pineapple, and a cherry. Serve with a straw.

name: Planter's Punch No. 1
instructions: Mix first three ingredients in collins glass, add ice cubes, and stir until glass is frosted. Add bitters and rum. Stir and top with grenadine. Decorate with slices of lemon, orange, and pineapple, and a cherry. Serve with a straw.

name: Planter's Punch No. 1
instructions:
Stir rum, lime juice, syrup, and bitters in ice-filled Collins glass
until glass is frosted. Fill with soda water and top with grenadine.
Garnish with the fruit. Serve with a straw.

name: Planter's Punch No. 2
instructions: Pour above into 16 oz. glass, well filled with shaved ice. stir until glass is frosted. Then add 1 oz. Jamaica Rum. and top with 1/4 teaspoon Old Mr. Boston Curacao. Decorate with slice of orange, lemon, pineapple and a cherry, also sprig of mint dipped in powdered sugar. Serve with straws.

name: Planter's Punch No. 2

name: Planter's Punch No. 2

Decorate with slices of orange, lemon, pineapple, and a cherry, also sprig of mint dipped in powdered sugar. Serve with a straw.

instructions:

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.

name: Robert E. Lee Cooler
instructions:
Into 12 oz. Tom Collins glass, put:
Juice 1/2 Lime 
1/2 Teaspoon Powdered Sugar 
2 oz. Carbonated Water, and stir.
Fill glass with Cracked Ice and add: 
1/4 Teaspoon Absinthe Substitute 
2 oz. Old Mr. Boston Dry Gin
Fill with Ginger Ale

Insert spiral of orange or lemon peel (or both) and dangle end over rim of glass.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Combine first four ingredients in ice-filled Collins glass. With bar
spoon between your palms, move hands back and forth and up and down to quickly rotate and lift spoon, until glass is frosted. Top with soda water. Serve with a swizzle stick.

name: Salty Dog
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Summer cocktails demand lighter spirits to brighten the fruit forward tipples, and in cocktails with only two ingredients, quality is key.  Sunset Hills Small Batch gin, with its smooth body and fresh taste creates a tasty premium cocktail.
instructions:
Rim highball glass with lemon and salt. Fill with ice. Add vodka and
grapefruit juice and stir.
notes: The Salty Dog is a slight variation on the Greyhound, which is simply gin or vodka with grapefruit juice. The flavor profile of gin tends to have much more depth than that of vodka, but hey, to each his or her own, right? All you need to do to transform your Greyhound into a Salty Dog is add a salted rim. Salt and gin might sound like an odd combination, but the salt really interacts with the grapefruit juice. If straight grapefruit is too sour for your taste, you can always add a dash of simple syrup to tone it down. Just be careful and don't overdo it, or you'll cancel out the salt.

name: Whiskey Swizzle
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Pour whiskey, lime juice, syrup, and bitters into Collins glass. Fill
glass with ice and stir. Add ice and fill with soda. With barspoon
between your palms, move hands back and forth and up and down to
quickly rotate and lift spoon, until glass is frosted.

name: Whiskey Toddy (Hot)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Blanton's bourbons is full of complex aromas of vanilla, mint and molasses. It's smooth sweet to the taste of brown sugar and spice make it an excellent bourbon for the Hot Toddy.
instructions:
Stir sugar and water in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug to
dissolve sugar. Add whiskey and stir. Add lemon and sprinkle with
nutmeg.
notes: The Hot Toddy holds a place in history as a restorative draught intended to cure the common cold. Of course, there is no scientific evidence to suggest that there is any truth to this theory, and modern medicine would discourage such forms of self-medication. Doctors these days…ever the skeptics. There are two main theories about the origin of this cocktail's name. The more poetic of the two comes from Tod's Well, which was Edinburgh's water source in the 18th century. The more plausible one, however, comes from the name for an Indian drink made from fermented sap of different types of toddy palm trees. These drinks were absorbed into the British Empire and adapted to British tastes. As with all cocktails of this straightforward style, there are myriad variations to be made. To spice things up, try substituting tea or apple cider for the water.

name: Zombie
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: George Bowman Small Batch Dark Rum's subtle aroma of coconut and vanilla and rich flavors of molasses make it a great rum for the fruity, fun, and potent Zombie.
instructions:
Shake with ice and pour into chilled Collins glass. Garnish with
mint.
notes: There are two prevailing theories about the Zombie. The first is that it was named for the effect it could have on those who imbibed in its tiki goodness. The second is that it was a sort of tiki version of the corpse reviver, designed to bring back from the dead those who had over-indulged the night before. Either way, the fact is that the three different types of rum in this drink make it a little freaky to say the least. Like any good tiki drink, it's bursting with fruit flavor, but bitters and demerara lend this cocktail a much more complex flavor profile. All in all, this cocktail is absolutely delicious, but be careful—it's just as likely to cause a hangover as it is to cure one.

name: Christmas Yule Eggnog
instructions:
Beat the yolks and whites of 1 Dozen Eggs separately and then pour together and add:
1 Pinch Baking Soda
6 oz. Old Mr. Boston Imported Rum
2 lbs. Granulated Sugar
Beat into stiff batter. Then add: 
1 qt. Milk
1 qt. Sweet Cream
2 qts. Old Mr. Boston Whiskey *
Stir. Set in refrigerator over night. Before serving, stir again, and serve in 4 oz. punch glasses, and grate nutmeg on top.

name: Christmas Yule Eggnog

name: Christmas Yule Eggnog
instructions:
Beat first the yolks and then, in a separate bowl, the whites of 1 dozen eggs. Pour them together and add:
1 inch Baking Soda
6 oz. Light Rum
2 lbs. Granulated Sugar
Beat into stiff batter. Then add:
32 oz. Milk
32 oz. Light Cream
1.75 liter Blended Whiskey 
Stir. Set in refrigerator overnight. Before serving, stir again, and serve in punch glasses. Sprinkle nutmeg on top.

name: Irish Coffee
instructions: Into a pre-warmed 8 oz. stemmed glass (or coffee cup), pour 1 1/2 oz. Irish Whiskey. Add 1 or 2 teaspoons sugar and fill to within 1/2 inch of top with strong, very hot black coffee. Stir to dissolve sugar. Float to brim with chilled whipped cream. Do not stir. Drink through floating cream.

name: Irish Coffee
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Concannon Irish Whiskey with its light body and flavors of sweet honey, spice and oak make it an excellent foundation for an Irish Coffee.
instructions:
Stir sugar cubes and coffee in preheated Irish coffee glass to
dissolve sugar. Add whiskey. Float cream over back of barspoon to
fill glass.
notes: In comparison to Irish whiskey, the Irish Coffee is actually a fairly recent invention. In the 1940s, the most common air route between America and Europe included a stop in Foynes, an air base near Limerick, Ireland. Given the temperamental nature of the weather in western Ireland though, short layovers often turned into overnight stays. On a winter's night in 1942, a particularly nasty storm sent a plane back to Foynes for the night. The restaurant was notified to prepare food and drink as usual, but chef Joe Sheridan decided to prepare something special for the passengers aboard the plane. Legend has it that one American passenger asked if he was drinking Brazilian coffee. “No,” Joe answered, “that's Irish Coffee.” Eventually, the recipe was discovered by travel writer Stanton Delaplane, who took it back to San Francisco with him, where it became a signature cocktail at the Buena Vista Hotel.
