name: Glogg
instructions:
Pour following into kettle:
4/5 qt. Claret Wine
4/5 qt. Port Wine
Insert cheesecloth bag containing:
2 oz. Dried Orange Peel
2 oz. Cinnamon Sticks
20 Cardamon Seeds
25 Cloves
and boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour 4/5 qt. of Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy over sugar making sure to saturate all of it. The light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot in punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

name: Glogg
instructions:
Pour following into kettle: 
2 4/5 Qts. Wine (Port, Sherry, Claret, Burgundy or Madeira) 
Insert cheesecloth bag containing:
2 oz. Dried Orange Peel
2 oz. Cinnamon Sticks
20 Cardamon Seeds
25 Cloves 
and boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour 4/5 qt. of Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy over sugar making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot in punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

name: Glogg
instructions: Into kettle pour 2 bottles of wine. Insert a cheesecloth bag containing: 2 oz. dried orange peel, 2 oz. cinnamon sticks, 20 cardamom seeds and 25 cloves. Boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour one fifth of Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy over sugar making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot in punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

and boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour one fifth of Old Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy over sugar making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. name: Glogg
instructions: Pour 2 750 ml bottles of wine into a kettle. Insert cheesecloth bag containing dried orange peel, cinnamon sticks, cardamom seeds and cloves. Boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb lump sugar over opening. Pour one 750 ml of Mr. Boston Five Star Brandy over sugar making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted, replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot i punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

name: Glogg
instructions: Pour the wine into a kettle. Insert cheesecloth bag containing remaining ingredients and boil slowly for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add 1 lb. each blanched almonds and seedless raisins and continue to boil for additional 15 minutes. Remove kettle from stove and place wire grill containing 1 lb. lump sugar over opening. Pour one 750-ml Brandy over sugar, making sure to saturate all of it. Then light sugar with match and let it flame. After sugar has melted, replace kettle cover to extinguish flame. Stir again and remove spice bag. Serve hot in punch cups with a few almonds and raisins.

name: Mai-Tai

Serve with straws.

Shake without ice. Strain into an ice-filled old-fashioned glass.
Garnish with skewered pineapple, cherry, and mint.
notes: The Mai-Tai is a bit of a drama queen, to be honest. The first one was created in 1933 by Don the Beachcomber at his restaurant in Hollywood. Eleven years later Victor J. Bergeron created a different drink by the same name at his eponymous California restaurant, Trader Vic's. For the sake of time, we'll spare you all the details. Just know that both men claimed to have created this cocktail. According to legend, the first person to taste Trader Vic's version cried out “Maita'i roa ae!” which translates roughly to “Out of this world! The best!” or something along those lines. Don't worry though, you don't need to speak Tahitian to enjoy it. The Mai-Tai has been butchered over the years, and many bars will serve you something neon with an umbrella if you order one. A true Mai-Tai is rich, amber, and rum-heavy—tiki style at its finest.

name: Artillery
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
A clean classic gin is needed for the Artillery cocktail. This sweet variation on the traditional gin martini highlights the herbal qualities of the sweet vermouth. Fleischmann's spicy aromas which are followed by crisp celery and pine, create a wonderfully aromatic, and flavorful cocktail.  

Instead of Angostura bitters, consider Peychaud’s Bitters - a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: We owe this classic southern cocktail to the Chatham Artillery, Georgia's oldest military unit. The fine folks of Savannah have been mixing up this potent potable since at least the late 1700s. Legend has it that sometime around 1791, George Washington came to visit the Chatham Artillery on short notice. In keeping with their southern hospitality, the artillery members and their wives threw together what they had on hand and created this punch, which they then served at a ball in the president's honor. The punch was a hit and became a southern tradition, often being mixed in horse buckets when served in larger quantities. Watch out for this one. Like many delicious cocktails, it's been known to sneak up on people.

name: Bloody Mary
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: A clean, smooth, refreshing vodka is key in a Bloody Mary, which makes Platinum Vodka an excellent choice. Though many modern alterations on the recipe call for flavored vodkas, the original is perfectly represented with a bright, unflavored vodka, that enhances the fresh flavors of a well crafted Bloody Mary.
instructions: Roll with ice between both halves of Boston shaker. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish with lime and celery.
notes: All hail the Bloody Mary, queen of cocktails and hair of the dog incarnate, gracing brunch tables everywhere since, well…sometime in the early 1900s. Most everyone is familiar with at least some variation of this drink. The original version was said to be nothing but half vodka and half tomato juice. Luckily, people have been adding multitudes of spices, seasonings, and any other kind of flourish you can imagine for almost a century. More recent trends tend to revolve around the garnish. One can easily find a Bloody Mary with practically an entire salad and even meat served atop it for brunch on Sunday mornings. Many versions also make use of other base spirits such as gin, tequila, bourbon, or rye. Whatever your taste, this classic pick-me-up is sure to be easy to find in most any bar.

name: Golden Cadillac
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This disco era cocktail is a sweet, and creamy after dinner treat. Mr. Boston's White Cream de Cacao is an excellent choice, with its rich chocolate flavor and notes of vanilla perfectly pairing with the sweet orange Galliano and cream.
instructions:
Combine with 1/2 cup crushed ice in blender on low speed for 10
seconds. Pour into chilled champagne flute.
notes: Grab your old letterman's jacket and head on down to Poor Red's BBQ in California gold country if you want to sample one of these creamy creations. After allegedly winning his bar in a game of dice, Poor Red started serving up some of the best barbecue El Dorado had ever tasted. Sometime in the early 50s, a couple came in and asked the bartender to mix up a new cocktail to celebrate their recent engagement. The bartender noticed that the couple had arrived in a brand new golden Cadillac and decided to make a drink to match it. This is the recipe he came up with. The Golden Cadillac became so popular that Galliano eventually gifted Poor Red's with their very own Golden Cadillac to display outside the restaurant. Pretty hip, huh?

name: Harvey Wallbanger
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Platinum vodka's clean, refreshing flavor makes it an excellent choice for the Harvey Wallbanger. It's bright, crisp flavor enhances the sweet fruit, while its use of corn in the distillation pair perfectly with the Galliano for a smooth creamy finish.
instructions:
Stir vodka and orange juice in Collins glass. Add ice and stir again.
Float Galliano on top.
notes: The 70s were by no means the pinnacle of mixology. It was a decade riddled with sloppy drinks made with every shortcut bartenders could dream up. The Harvey Wallbanger, however, is an exception. It is one of the few recipes from that era that can stand up to the craft cocktail craze that has swept the nation over the past few years. Think of it as one of those Screwdrivers you used to drink back in college, but with a tasteful twist. Supposedly, the Harvey Wallbanger was named after a bar regular at Duke's Blackwatch Bar in Hollywood in 1952. Several years later, the company that imported Galliano discovered the drink and created a surfer-themed marketing campaign with the catchphrase, “Harvey Wallbanger's the name, and I can be made!” From there, the Harvey Wallbanger took off like a pair of speed skates at a roller disco.

name: Hurricane
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Hurricane is a sweet and fruity cocktail that calls for quite a bit of rum. Using Calypso white rum, with its light, sweet sugary flavor will blend perfectly with the fruit flavors creating a balanced cocktail that is not over powered by the rum.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled hurricane glass. Garnish with orange and cherry.
notes: This French Quarter mainstay first made landfall sometime in the 1940s at Pat O'Brien's bar in New Orleans. Supposedly, the bar began as a speakeasy with the password “Storm's brewin'”—perhaps foretelling the creation of this cocktail. It would appear that Mr. O'Brien came up with the Hurricane in an effort to empty his stores of the large quantities of rum that his southern distributors required him to buy, hence the ample dosing of both light and dark rum. He poured his new concoction into glasses shaped like hurricane lamps and dubbed it the Hurricane. This cocktail is sticky-sweet and bursting with juicy flavors. Be careful though. It packs a category-five punch.

notes: The story of the Negroni is a curious tale indeed. Sometime around 1920, an Italian Count named Camillo Negroni, who had recently returned from working as a rodeo cowboy in America—yes, a rodeo cowboy—went to a caffè. There, he ordered his favorite drink, an Americano, but requested that the bartender liven it up a bit by replacing the soda water with gin. The bartender also replaced the Americano's traditional lemon slice with an orange slice and named the drink after the Count.  For years, the Negroni was an Italian favorite, but it didn't leave home until well into the 21st century. A full-throttle cocktail renaissance had opened Americans back up to the taste of gin and bitters, so the moment was finally right for the Negroni to make it's way to America, where it has become a mainstay on cocktail menus everywhere.

Ramon "Monchito" Marrero at the Caribe Hilton's Beachcomber Bar in
San Juan, PR, in 1954, at the time when cream of coconut was just hitting
the marketplace.

instructions: Into old-fashioned glass put a small cube of sugar, a dash of Angostura bitters, a teaspoon of water and muddle well. Add 2 oz. Desmond &Duff Scotch Whiskey. Stir. Add twist of lemon peel and ice cubes. Decorate with slice of orange, lemon, and a cherry. Serve with a swizzle stick.

name: Scotch Old Fashioned
instructions:
Make same as Old Fashioned (see page 131) but substitute Desmond & Duff Scotch.

Into an old fashioned glass, put a small cube of sugar, a dash of bitters, a teaspoon of water, and muddle well. Add 2 oz. Desmond & duff scotch. Stir. Add a twist of lemon peel and ice cubes. Decorate with slices of orange, lemon, and a cherry. Serve with a swizzle stick.

name: Charlie Chaplin
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Charlie Chaplin is a simple stirred cocktail that requires a premium bourbon with a flavorful body and smooth finish. Elmer T Lee Bourbon's rich flavor or vanilla and leather find a wonderful balance with the sherry and amaro, creating a complex, multilayered cocktail that still highlights the bourbon.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cordial glass.
notes: Charlie Chaplin, undoubtedly one of the most beloved figures in cinematic history and a jack-of-all-trades of the industry, was active in film for over 75 years. The Charlie Chaplin was created when its namesake was at the pinnacle of his career. First recorded in Albert Stevens Crockett's The Old Waldorf-Astoria Bar Book in 1935, this cocktail was served in the original Waldorf-Astoria hotel in New York City up until the 1920s. Due to the tremendous technological advancements of the early 20th century, the Waldorf-Astoria quickly grew outdated and its wealthy clientele drifted elsewhere. Consequently, it was sold and demolished in 1929 to make way for the Empire State Building. The current Waldorf-Astoria was opened in 1931, but the Charlie Chaplin never seemed to make it back onto the cocktail menu. This bittersweet, fruity mixture is sure to satisfy any sweet tooth and pairs great with salty bar snacks.

name: Amaretto Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Amaretto Sours are a sweet nutty cocktail that calls for a full bodied spirit to pair with the bright citrus and sugar. di Amore Amaretto is an excellent choice with its rich body and caramel, almond flavors.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled sour glass. Garnish with orange.
notes: The history behind the Amaretto Sour is lost to the ages. Like many sweeter cocktails, this one often gets a bad rap, but fear not. Balancing out the sticky sweetness that the almond-flavored amaretto liqueur imparts to this drink is actually fairly simple. The first step is to ensure that the amaretto used is of good quality since it is the backbone of this cocktail's flavor. Second, use freshly squeezed, unsweetened juice to maximize the crisp, tart flavors needed to achieve a well-balanced drink. An egg white is always a welcome addition and will help to smooth out the boldness of these flavors as well. Fun fact: most amaretto contains no almonds at all, and actually gets its flavor from apricot pits—although for anyone who may be allergic, it's still a good idea to check the label.

name: Americano

notes: Just like it's caffeinated cousin, the Caffè Americano, the Americano cocktail was born in Italy. Originally though, it was known as the Milano-Torino, as Campari came from Milan and Punt e Mes came from Turin. Legend has it that when Italian bar-goers noticed a surge of Americans imbibing this particular concoction, they dubbed in the Americano, and the name stuck. In Ian Fleming's Casino Royale series, the Americano is the first drink ordered by the infamous James Bond himself. Gaspare Campari, for whom Campari liqueur is named, first served it at his famous Caffè Campari in Milan in 1860. Like so many Italian cocktails, it is an impeccable balance of sweet and bitter enhanced by refreshing herbal notes. Perfect with antipasti or just as a before-dinner drink.

name: Between-The-Sheets
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso white rum, when used in the Between the Sheets cocktail gives depth and sweetness to the cognac with its distinct cane sugar flavor. It's natural sweetness helps to tie the triple sec, tart lemon, and rich cognac together to create a smooth, well balanced cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled shot glass.
notes: Now here's a cocktail that will make you blush. Or at least it will make your cheeks turn red. As David Wondrich puts it, the Between the Sheets dates back to Prohibition, a time when America's moral fiber wasn't what it should've been—but than again, neither was its liquor supply. There are many provocative theories about the origins of this cocktail, but most people agree that it was first created sometime in the 1930s at Harry's New York Bar in Paris. Others say it traces back to the Berkeley Hotel in London. The truth is, as with many popular drinks, no one is really sure. A word of caution: though delicious, this cocktail is not to be taken lightly. Too many of these will have you reaching for the aspirin tomorrow morning.

name: Daiquiri
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The daiquiri is one of the original "sour' cocktails, which is a combination of spirit, sugar, and juice. Because there are so few ingredients, quality and balance are key. Calypso white rum has a light, sweet sugar can flavor, that supports the other ingredients, and balances nicely to create a simply delicious classic.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Cuba holds a special place in history for many reasons—among them, the Daiquiri. In the small town of Daïquiri in 1898, Jennings Stockton Cox, an American engineer, led one of the earliest efforts to exploit Cuba's iron-ore mines. As recompense for leaving his secure position in the US, Cox was given generous wages and a ration of Bacardí Carta Blanca. According to legend, Cox was running low on gin one evening while entertaining guests, so he mixed up a punch with limes, sugar, and rum. Cox and his team took to drinking this new concoction and dubbed it the Daiquiri in honor of the city where they lived. The recipe eventually made its way back to the States and became a mainstay for cocktail bars. Bartender's note: for a truly authentic Daiquiri, use Bacardí Superior, which is made using the same recipe and yeast strain as Bacardí Carta Blanca.

name: Gimlet

notes: Medicine isn't nearly as much fun as it used to be. The Gimlet was actually invented by naval surgeons for the British Merchant Navy to help prevent sailors from getting scurvy. In the past, the British were often referred to as “Limeys” due to their penchant for sucking on limes for vitamin C. But when Navy doctors began noticing that sailors were throwing theirs out, they concocted this refreshing little tipple to better ensure the health of their patients. Apparently a spoonful of sugar—and a couple of ounces of gin—really does help the medicine go down. The recipe eventually made it back to the mainland and is still an anchor on cocktail lists to this day. As for scurvy, it hasn't posed a real health threat in quite some time, but hey, better safe than sorry.

name: Long Island Iced Tea
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka create a refreshing Long Island Iced Tea, while it's smooth, buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the tart lemon, providing a much better balanced drink
instructions:
Shake ingredients, except cola, with ice and pour with ice into
highball glass. Add cola for color. Add lemon.
notes: If you're looking for a strong drink, look no further. This powerful combination of five different spirits is sure to get you where you want to go. The interesting thing about the Long Island Iced Tea—or LIT, as it's commonly referred to—is that while it doesn't contain a single drop of actual tea, it certainly looks like tea and even tastes a bit like it. The LIT is treacherous though because it goes down so easily. Mention it at a party, and you're bound to end up listening to a string of anecdotes from every person there about that one time they drank Long Island Iced Teas on a night out. At any rate, this cocktail is sure to bring on the good times, whether you remember them or not. Beware, though, the hangover can be rough, so be sure to take preventative measures.

name: Margarita
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Monte Alban Silver is an excellent choice of tequila in a margarita, as its fruity, floral aromas pair perfectly with the bright citrus. Its creamy finish gives this sour cocktail balance and body.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lime and salt. Shake remaining
ingredients with ice and strain into glass.
notes: The origins of the Margarita are positively shrouded in mystery. The stories laying claim to its creation are as numerous and as colorful as the spectrum of Margarita variations floating around bars today. In many of those stories the drink is named after a woman. In 1945, Jose Cuervo, began running an ad campaign with the slogan, “Margarita: It's more than just a girl's name.” The campaign was a huge success, and the Margarita went on to become one of America's favorite cocktails. The Margarita is a derivative of a family of drinks called Daisies, and in one story, a bartender creates the Margarita accidentally by mistakenly grabbing a bottle of tequila while preparing a Brandy Daisy. According to legend, the customer was delighted with the result, and spread the news far and wide. The bartender decided to call his drink a “Margarita” which is Spanish for “Daisy”.

name: Martini
instructions: serve with an olive.
notes: Dry, dirty, up, on the rocks, with a twist, shaken—not stirred. The possibilities for specifications on a Martini are endless and often intimidating. The Martini is timeless. It's chic and sophisticated. Cocktail fads come and go, but the Martini has proven resilient, which is perhaps one of the reasons it stands above other cocktails. There are countless myths and legends recounting the alleged creation of this cocktail and each is as unlikely as the next when compared with history. Similar “Martini” recipes have cropped up throughout time all over the country, each bearing a unique twist in its ingredients or proportions. Often they share similar but not identical nomenclature—Martini, Martinez, Martine, Martigny, just to name a few. The truth is that the origins of this cocktail are likely to remain shrouded in mystery. But perhaps that's for the best. After all, solving the enigma breaks the legend.

name: Melon Ball
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Mr. Boston Melon liqueur is a excellent choice for this fruity melon cocktail with its vibrant green color and sweet honeydew flavor, that are perfectly balanced by the vodka and tart orange juice to create a delicious cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cordial glass.
notes: Perhaps you've heard of a place called Studio 54. In case you haven't, here's a little background. Studio 54 was arguably the most famous nightclub in the world from 1977 to 1979. Located in Manhattan, this venue was a magnet for celebrities. Actors, artists, fashion designers, musicians; Studio 54 probably served at least one drink to nearly every famous name of the era that you can think of. And a good number of those drinks were likely Melon Balls. This cocktail packs quite a punch when it comes to flavor. Many recipes call for orange instead of pineapple juice, but the pineapple really highlights the bright, sweet flavor of the melon. The recipe can also be easily adapted to pitchers if you're hosting guests and drinks particularly well on the patio in summer. If you have a melon baller, try scooping out balls of honeydew and freezing them for ice.

name: Pink Lady
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin is a great choice for the Pink Lady with its bright candied lemon and spicy juniper aromas, that perfectly pair with the rich sweetness of the grenadine
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled red wine

notes: The Pink Lady, like many pink drinks, has been the object of sexism for many decades. This cocktail was already being served prior to the Prohibition era, but rose to prominence during those dark days when alcohol was a crime in America due to a need to mask the unpleasant flavors of bathtub gin and the like. After Prohibition, the Pink Lady was heaped in with all the other “girly drinks” and fell out of favor with male cocktail critics. At one point, it even ended up on Esquire's list of the ten worst cocktails. The truth is that this cocktail is no sweeter than most others and actually has a pretty complex flavor profile due in part to applejack and real grenadine. We think it's time to give the Pink Lady another chance. After all, sexism is so 20th century.

name: Sangria
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy's smooth sweet aromatics along with rich fruit flavors make it a great choice for Sangria. It's notes of orange peel, apricots and vanilla enhance the fruit and the wine, while the tart alcohol leaves a crisp, balanced finish.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled red-wine glass. Garnish with
cinnamon and orange twist.
notes: The history of Sangria is fairly simple. As Rome conquered Europe, they continued expanding outward, eventually reaching the Iberian Peninsula, which is what we know as Spain and Portugal today. On their way, the Romans planted grapes to be able to make wine. At the time, water wasn't safe to drink, so it was a common practice to add alcohol, herbs, spices, and anything else that might kill of bacteria. The problem was that the table wine was so terrible that people would do anything to mask the flavor. This included adding fruit, juices, and even other types of alcohol to the wine in order to make it more palatable. Water may have since been made safe to drink, but the practice of making punch out of wine hasn't faded. Let's hope it never does.

name: White Russian
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The crisp, clean taste of Rain Vodka make it an excellent choice for the White Russian, as it blends well with the rich coffee liqueur and cuts the richness of the cream to create a well balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Pour vodka and coffee liqueur into ice-filled old-fashioned glass.
Fill with milk or half-and-half.
notes: When vodka first hit the American market around the middle of the 20th century, cocktail books often referred to vodka recipes as “Russians” because vodka was generally imported from—you guessed it—Russia. The predecessor to the White Russian was the Black Russian, which came along around 1949. The Black Russian is simply a White Russian without cream, hence the change of color. The White Russian was first documented in the mid 60s. From there it experienced a brief surge in popularity during the disco era, but fell out of favor until the release of the film The Big Lebowski in 1998, in which the character played by Jeff Bridges downs eight White Russians and drops a ninth one on the floor. White Russians can be drunk as a morning beverage if you're trying to cure a hangover, but be careful—drinking too many of them will only cause one.

name: Bellini
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Mr. Boston Peach Schnapps is a great choice for a bellini. It's fresh peach flavor and richly sweet body make it an excellent alternative to peach puree for this bubbly celebration cocktail.
instructions:
Pour puree into chilled Champagne flute. Carefully fill glass with
prosecco (watch out for foaming).
notes: Simplicity. It's the mark of a true Bellini. Fresh white peach puree and crisp, fizzy Prosecco. Italian summers are heavily perfumed by the abundant number of peaches that grow throughout the country, and there is a long history there of marinating these succulent fruits in local wines. In 1948, Giuseppe Cipriani created the first Bellini at Harry's Bar in Venice in an attempt to transform his favorite fruit into a cocktail for his patrons. His invention was a huge success, but the Bellini remained a seasonal treat until a French entrepreneur devised a method of freezing the fresh peach puree so that Mr. Cipriani could serve them year-round. The name is said to be inspired by the colors used by Venetian painter Giovanni Bellini in many of his works. An excellent choice for brunch, but perfect for humid summer evenings spent outdoors.

name: Blue Hawaiian
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Though a supporting ingredient in this rum based cocktail, the Blue Curacao is the true star in this tiki cocktail invented at the Hilton Hawaiian. Mr. Boston's Blue Curacao with it's sweet orange taste and electric blue color are perfect for this creamy tropical drink.
instructions:
Combine ingredients with 1 cup crushed ice in blender on high
speed. Pour into chilled highball glass. Garnish with pineapple and
cherry.
notes: Blue drinks have long been a source of controversy in the bar community. Most of them take their color from blue Curaçao, which is actually an orange liqueur that has been dyed with blue food coloring. The Dutch brought blue Curaçao to the European market sometime in the 19th century along with an entire spectrum of colored liqueurs. These brightly colored concoctions quickly made their way across the Atlantic and rose in popularity until Prohibition stamped them out in the US. It wasn't until 1957 that blue drinks made their way back into American pop culture, when Harry Yee created the Blue Hawaiian at the Hilton Hawaii Village in Waikiki. You can think of the Blue Hawaiian as the Piña Colada's flashier cousin. If you're in need of a little taste of a tropical getaway, this may be just the tonic you're looking for.

name: Chi Chi
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The freshness and bright aromatics of Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin pair harmoniously with the citrus and mint in the Southside cocktail. This summer cocktail is best supported by a light smooth gin with nuanced botanicals instead of a traditional London Dry.
instructions:
Process ingredients with 1 cup crushed ice in blender until smooth.
Pour into red-wine glass. Garnish with pineapple and cherry.
notes: Think of the Chi-Chi as the Piña Colada's drier cousin. Pineapple and coconut lend a similar flavor profile to that of the Piña Colada, while the use of vodka instead of rum cuts back on the sugar. A good way to dip your toes in the water for those who aren't necessarily huge tiki fans, and a great alternative for anyone who gets a stomach ache after too many sugary drinks. This drink is generally credited to Donn Beach, or as most people knew him, “Don the Beachcomber”, who founded several tiki bars and restaurant and influenced the tiki fad a great deal in the 40s and 50s. For a truly authentic version, don't hold back on the garnishes. If you're feeling extra festive, you might even try serving your Chi-Chis in hollowed out pineapples. Although, glasses work just as well.

name: Madras
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the bright fruity flavors of the Madras while it's smooth, rich texture will cut the tart sweetness of the cranberry and orange juice, providing a wonderfully balanced drink
instructions:
Build in order given into ice-filled highball glass. Squeeze lime and
add.
notes: The Madras is one of those nice refreshing cocktails that can really be drunk at any time of year—or day for that matter. It is uncomplicated and easy, accessible and straightforward. A perfect drink if you've had a long day at work and don't want to intellectually invest in appreciating a dauntingly complex cocktail. Plus it's largely fruit juice, so of course it's rich in vitamins and minerals—and sugar. The simplicity of the Madras makes it easy to whip up, even on a moment's notice. There is also plenty of room to play around with flavored vodkas and the like if you're feeling experimental.

name: Ramos Gin Fizz
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Ramos Gin Fizz is considered an "eye opener" cocktail, historically served to help those who consumed it wake up. It's tart, and creamy, and refreshing, and it calls for a bright, crisp gin. Sunset Hill's Small batch gin is an excellent choice, with its fresh botanical blend and light, smooth body.
instructions:
Shake all ingredients except soda water without ice well until foamy.
Add ice and shake well until chilled. Strain into chilled highball
glass. Top with soda water and stir.
notes: The Ramos Gin Fizz is one of New Orleans's most famous cocktails. When Henry C. Ramos invented this cocktail in 1888 at the Imperial Cabinet Saloon, his recipe called it to be shook for 12 minutes straight. To keep up with the demand, Mr. Ramos kept at least 20 people behind the bar making nothing but Ramos Gin Fizzes at all times. During certain festivals and holidays, he was known to have up to 32. After the end of Prohibition, this cocktail was revived, but the 12-minute shake time was left in the grave. It has a particularly frothy body as well as a remarkably sweet floral note imparted by the orange blossom water.

name: Canyon Quake

name: Citrus-Beer Punch
instructions: Remove peel from lemons and set aside. Juice lemons (about 2 cups juice). In large saucepan, stir together sugar and water. Bring to boiling and add reserved lemon peel. Remove from heat. Cover and let stand 5 minutes. remove and discard peel. Add lemon juice and grapefruit juice and grapefruit juice to sugar mixture. Transfer mixture to a 3-quart pitcher; cover and chill. Just before serving, add beer. Pour into glass mugs over cracked ice and garnish with lemon slices. Makes 8 servings.

name: Citrus-Beer Punch

Add lemon zest and remove from heat. Cover and let stand 5 minutes. Add lemon juice and grapefruit juice. Strain into large pitcher, cover, and refrigerate until chilled. Just before serving, add beer. Serve in punch cups, garnished with lemon wheels.

name: Coffee Old-Fashioned
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:

glass and stir. Add soda water and stir again. Garnish with orange
and cherry.

name: French Martini

name: French Martini
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The French Martini is a delightfully sweet cocktail that when paired with a clean, refreshing vodka, can suit all palates. Rain vodka, with its smooth taste due to its addition of limestone water creates a wonderfully balanced fruity cocktail able to please introductory drinkers and aficionados alike.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: In all honesty, there isn't a lot about this cocktail that one might call “French”. The only truly French ingredient is Chambord, a black raspberry liqueur made in France's Loire Valley region. Between the Chambord and the Pineapple juice (which, as always, had better be fresh) this cocktail is unapologetically fruity. It makes a great drink for those who don't want to be overwhelmed by the taste their alcohol. For those who like a little more kick, some recipes call for gin instead of vodka. Either way, the key to making a great French Martini is to really shake the heck out of it. This will cause the pineapple juice to froth, which adds both to the presentation and the body of the drink. As the French would say, À la vôtre!
