name: The All-American Daiquiri
instructions: For red layer (light rum or vodka, and strawberry daiquiri mix) and blue layer (light rum or vodka, sour mix and blueberry flavoring) combine ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice and blend until very thick. Layer frozen colors-blue, red, and white (whipped cream) - in parfait glass. Top with a cherry and an American flag frill pick.

name: The Big Chill
instructions: Combine ingredients in blender with 1 scoop ice and blend until smooth. Serve in 12-oz. pilsner glass and garnish with a pineapple wedge and a cherry.

name: The Big Chill
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into hurricane or pilsner glass. Garnish with pineapple and
cherry.

name: The Blizzard
instructions: Combine ingredients in blender and blend until smooth. Pour into a large snifter and garnish with a sprinkle of nutmeg.

name: The Blizzard
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender until smooth. Pour into large snifter.
Top with nutmeg.

name: The Brass Fiddle
instructions: Combine first 4 ingredients in blender with ice and blend until smooth. Pour frozen mixture into a parfait glass that has been swirled with grenadine. Garnish with a pineapple slice and a cherry.

name: The Brass Fiddle
instructions:
Swirl grenadine inside hurricane glass to coat inside. Do not discard
excess. Process remaining ingredients in blender with 1 cup ice until
smooth. Pour into glass. Garnish with pineapple and cherry.

name: Thoroughbred Cooler
instructions: Pour all ingredients over ice in highball glass. Fill with lemon-lime soda and stir. Add dash of grenadine, garnish with an orange wedge.

name: Thoroughbred Cooler
instructions:
Pour first four ingredients over ice in highball glass. Fill with
lemon-lime soda and stir. Add grenadine. Garnish with orange.

name: Thunder Cloud
instructions: Fill hurricane or parfait glass with ice. layer ingredients in order given. Whirl gently with a large straw.

name: Tidal Wave
instructions: Combine ingredients in blender with ice and blend until smooth. Pour into parfait glass. Garnish with a lime wheel and a cherry.

name: Tidal Wave
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into hurricane glass. Garnish with lime and cherry.

name: Tijuana Taxi
instructions: Pour tequila, curacao, and schnapps over ice into large highball glass. Fill with lemon-lime soda and garnish with orange slice and a cherry.

name: Tijuana Taxi
instructions:
Pour first three ingredients into ice-filled large highball glass. Fill
with lemon-lime soda. Garnish with orange and cherry.

name: Tikki Dream
instructions: Pour over ice into sugar-rimmed highball glass. Garnish with a wedge of watermelon.

name: To The Moon
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into shot glass.

name: To The Moon
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled shot glass.

name: Traffic Light
instructions: Layer liqueurs in order given in cordial glass.

name: Traffic Light
instructions:
Float carefully, in order given, over back of barspoon into chilled
cordial or shot glass, so that each ingredient layers on preceding
one.

name: Traffic Light Cooler
instructions: Into pilsner glass filled with ice cubes, first pour the melon liqueur, then the tequila, to create a green layer. Add sour mix. Slowly pour orange juice against side of glass to create the yellow layer. Add a few more ice cubes, if needed. Carefully float the sloe gin on top for the red layer. Garnish with a cherry and lemon and lime wheels. Stir just before drinking.

name: Trolley Car
instructions: Combine ingredients in blender and blend until smooth. Pour into parfait glass and garnish with a fresh strawberry.

name: Trolley Car
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender until smooth. Pour into hurricane
glass. Garnish with whole strawberry.

name: Tropica Cocktail
instructions: Mix ingredients in collins glass filled with ice cubes. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

name: Tropica Cocktail
instructions: Mix ingredients in ice-filled Collins glass. Add pineapple wedge.

name: Tropical Cream Punch
instructions: In punch bowl, combine sweetened condensed milk and juice concentrates; mix well. Add club soda, stir gently. Add block of ice and garnish with orange slices. Makes 22 servings.

name: Tropical Cream Punch
instructions:
Whisk condensed milk and juice concentrates in punch bowl. Add
club soda and stir gently. Add block of ice and garnish with orange.
Serve in punch cups.

name: Tropical Iced Tea
instructions: Combine all ingredients in mixing glass and pour over ice in collins glass. Garnish with seasonal fruits.

name: Tropical Special
instructions: Shake with ice, then strain into highball glass over ice. Decorate with fruit slices and a cherry.

name: Tropical Special
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled highball glass. Garnish with
tropical fruits and cherry.

name: Twin Peach
instructions: Fill highball glass with ice. Add schnapps, fill with cranberry juice, and stir. Garnish with an orange or peach slice.

name: Twin Peach
instructions:
Pour schnapps into ice-filled highball glass, fill with cranberry
juice, and stir. Garnish with peach or orange.

name: Unfuzzy Navel
instructions: Combine ingredients in shaker with ice. Strain into red-wine glass. Garnish with an orange slice.

name: Unfuzzy Navel
instructions: Combine ingredients in shaker with ice. Strain into red-wine glass. Garnish with an orange slice.

name: Unfuzzy Navel
instructions:
Shake with ice. Strain into chilled red-wine glass. Garnish with
orange.

name: Velvet Hammer
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into cocktail glass.

name: Velvet Peach Hammer
instructions: Pour vodka and schnapps over ice into old-fashioned glass. Stir and top with sour mix. Garnish with a slice of fresh peach.

name: Velvet Peach Hammer
instructions:
Pour vodka and schnapps into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Stir
and top with syrup and lemon juice. Garnish with peach.

name: Wavebender
instructions: Shake juices and grenadine with ice and strain into highball glass filled with ice cubes. Top with ginger ale and stir.

name: Wavebender
instructions: Shake juices and grenadine with ice and strain into highball glass filled with ice cubes. Top with ginger ale and stir.

name: Wavebender
instructions:
Shake juices and grenadine with ice and strain into ice-filled
highball glass. Fill with ginger ale and stir.

name: Whiskey Sour Punch
instructions: Combine ingredients over block of ice in punch bowl. Stir gently. Garnish with orange slices. Makes 32 servings.

name: Whiskey Sour Punch
instructions:
Combine ingredients over block of ice in punch bowl. Stir gently.
Garnish with oranges. Serve in punch cups.

name: Wiki Waki Woo
instructions: Combine all ingredients with ice, pour into hurricane or parfait glass. Garnish with an orange slice and a cherry.

name: Wiki Waki Woo
instructions:
Stir all ingredients with ice. Pour, with ice, into hurricane or parfait
glass. Add orange and cherry.

name: Wild Thing
instructions: Pour over ice into old-fashioned glass. Garnish with a lime wheel.

name: Winter Cider
instructions: In large saucepan, bring cider and cinnamon to a full boil over medium heat. Reduce heat and add rum, brandy, and schnapps, stirring until heated through. Serve in Irish coffee glasses, garnished with a cinnamon stick and an apple slice. Makes 18-20 servings.

name: Yellowjacket
instructions: Shake with old-fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Garnish with a lemon slice.

name: Yellowjacket
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into old-fashioned glass filled with ice cubes. Garnish with a lemon slice.

name: Air Mail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso white rum's distinct sugar cane flavor, and light sweet body are perfect pairings for the honey syrup and dry champagne in the Air Mail cocktail.
instructions: Shake rum, lime juice, and syrup with ice. Strain into chilled champagne flute. Top with Champagne.
notes: Back in the mid-1900s, airmail was a common method for sending packages and letters, and was without a doubt the fastest way to get something from point A to point B. This cocktail derives its name from that very same idea—it's one of the quickest ways to get from A to B. The origins of the Air Mail are somewhat unclear. The recipe was first published in Esquire's Handbook for Hosts in 1949, but no one is quite sure exactly where it came from. Widely regarded as one of the better champagne cocktails, this fizzy concoction looks like liquid gold poured over ice and tastes like a Caribbean beach vacation in a glass. Email might have replaced airmail, but there's no substitute for this citrusy delight.

name: Alexander Cocktail No. 1 (Gin)
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Top with nutmeg.
notes:
Creamy and lush, the Brandy Alexander is a now-familiar after-dinner
drink. However, you might want to get to know the original version, made
with gin.

name: Amante Picante
instructions: Muddle 2 cucumber slices and cilantro in mixing glass. Add remaining ingredients. Shake with ice and double-strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cucumber.

name: Aviation
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Aviation calls for an assertive, traditional, but not overpowering gin to blend with aromatic flavors of the cremè de violette and maraschino. Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin has a traditional botanical blend of juniper, licorice, lemon, rose and cucumber, but its light body and smooth taste make it an exceptional choice for this bright, aromatic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cherry.
notes: The story of the Aviation cocktail is a bit of a Cinderella story. According to David Wondrich, it has been flying under the radar ever since it made its first appearance on a cocktail menu in 1911. Hugo Ensslin first published the recipe for this lovely little libation in his Recipes for Mixed Drinks in 1916, combining gin, lemon juice, maraschino and crème de violette liqueurs. Unfortunately maraschino and crème de violette weren't exactly commonplace on most bar shelves at the time, so the Aviation had a shaky takeoff. Eventually, crème de violette disappeared entirely from the American market, resulting in a mouth-puckering variation of the original recipe. When it finally reappeared some 40 years later, the Aviation was revived. Crème de violette adds a delicate floral note, which balances the tartness of the healthy dose of citrus and gin.

name: Bee's Knees
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The bright lemon, floral rose petal and juniper berry botanicals in the Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin pair perfectly with the lemon and honey in the Bee's Knees cocktail creating a beautifully aromatic, subtly sweet gin cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled champagne coupe.
notes: Get a wiggle on and head on down to the gin mill if this sounds like your kind of cocktail. First recorded in 1934 by William Boothby, this particular brand of giggle water is sure to please even the toughest of crowds and quench the most insatiable of thirsts. One of the niftiest things about summer is high-quality local honey, and the Bee's Knees is the perfect way to take advantage. If you're open to experimentation, try using different types of honey from different places. This can have a profound effect on the taste of this cocktail even for those who don't boast a well-trained palate. All in all, this stuff is the cat's meow.

name: Bourbon And Elder
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled old-fashioned glass. Add lemon
twist.

name: Bourbon Spice Latte
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass. Float star anise on top.

name: Brandy Alexander No. 2
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Hartley Brandy with its sweet caramel and butterscotch aromatics are a great pair for the chocolate and rich cream in the Brandy Alexander.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Top with nutmeg.
notes: Half-and-half is often used in cocktails to give them a luscious creaminess. Milk is used less often.

name: Brandy Crusta
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Hartley Brandy's rich buttery aroma along with notes of orange peel and apricot, make it a excellent choice for the Brandy Crusta. It's sweet fruit flavors enhance the fruit  while it's crisp balanced finish cuts the tart lemon producing a balanced cocktail.

Instead of Angostura bitters, consider New Orleans' own Peychaud’s Bitters - a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Curl the zest spiral
on its side in glass. Stir ingredients with ice and strain into glass.
Garnish with orange.
notes: There's a good chance you've never seen or heard of a Brandy Crusta, which is an unfortunate result of the circle of life of cocktails. The Crusta is actually the precursor to many a cocktail, including the Sidecar, the Cosmopolitan, and even the Margarita in a sense, but there is a noticeable difference at play in these recipes—proportions. The Brandy Crusta is essentially a healthy dose of brandy seasoned with mere dashes of other flavoring ingredients. This style of drink allows the drinker to really appreciate the base spirit without being overwhelmed by its potency. Perhaps the most impressive part of this cocktail is its lemon-shell garnish. Getting it right can take a bit of effort, but it's worth the trouble. If you're having trouble getting it to stay in place, try frosting the rim of the glass and the lemon peel and then letting them sit until a hard crust is formed.

name: Caipirinha
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: With Cachaca 51's Subtle grassy notes, your caipirinha will always turn out more balanced than if you had used a bolder more distinct cachaca, Cachaca 51 is the best choice for those who are just experimenting with this style of sugar cane spirit.
instructions:
Muddle lime and syrup in old-fashioned glass. Add cachaça and stir.
Fill with ice and stir again.
notes: Over the past few years, the Caipirinha has taken the world by storm. It was named the official drink of Brazil in 2003 by then President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, more commonly known to his constituency as “Lula”. Once Lula had given the Caipirinha official status, bars all over the globe began churning them out. The name essentially means “little peasant”, as it is thought to have been created in the small town of Piracicaba. Like many other cocktails, this one is believed to have medicinal origins. It seems to have appeared sometime in the early 20th century to fight off the Spanish flu, and originally included garlic and honey in the recipe. Those ingredients were eventually removed and replaced with sugar and ice. Though it might not be the most effective medical treatment around these days, a couple of these are sure to improve your Samba steps.

name: Chet Baker
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Muddle sugar cube with bitters in mixing glass. Add ice, then other
ingredients, and stir briefly. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned
glass. Garnish with lemon twist.

name: Chupa Cabra
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
lime.

name: Clover Club
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This fruity version of a gin sour, will be showcased best with the spicy, juniper botanicals of Fleischmann's gin. It's bright citrus notes will enhance the lemon and raspberry portions of the cocktail giving you a perfect balance of sweet and tart.
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled red wine
glass.
notes: The Clover Club was an assemblage of bankers, lawyers, and other prominent male professionals who met at the Bellevue-Stratford hotel in Philadelphia beginning in the 1880s and continuing on until the First World War. A veritable boys club, if you will. Like so many organizations of its kind, the Clover Club eventually disbanded, but it's members left behind this little gem for us to remember them by. Many people shy away from egg white these days, but in truth, it lends little to no flavor to drinks. Egg whites are merely used to add body and texture to cocktails. In this one, raspberry remains the dominant flavor but by no means overpowers. Some people like to garnish the Clover Club with a mint leave. Technically that's a Clover Leaf—but we'll let it slide. And gentlemen, this drink may be pink, but remember where it came from.

name: Corpse Reviver No. 1
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

name: Corpse Reviver No. 2
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The corpse reviver is all about balancing the bright citrus of the lemon and triple sec, and the herbal notes of the absinthe. The spicy coriander and pine of Fleischmann's Gin along with its citrus and herbal botanicals create a perfect bridge between the other ingredients, finding the balance which is key in the Corpse Reviver No.2
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The concept of “hair of the dog” has long been a source of debate amongst social drinkers. Science doesn't seem to have much to say on the matter, but bar-goers certainly do. In the early 20th century, bartenders swore by it so firmly that they created a whole arsenal of morning-after cocktails that they swore would get you back on your feet after an overly indulgent night out. Unfortunately, not many of these corpse revivers, as they were called, are still popular today. The Corpse Reviver #2 is the exception. This light, fragrant cocktail that is sure to refresh. It is also a great way to introduce people to gin and even absinthe since neither of them overpowers the other ingredients when this drink made properly. Snake oil or not, the Corpse Reviver #2 will not disappoint.

name: Cosmopolitan
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: With its rich buttery mellowness and cool crisp finish, Rain vodka is an excellent choice for the Cosmopolitan. The richness of this vodka balances the tart cranberry to create a wonderfully balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Shake well with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish
with lime.
notes: The legends surrounding the creation of the Cosmopolitan span multiple decades and numerous celebrities. It has generally been credited to one of two different bartenders, but a primitive version of this drink actually appeared on Ocean Spray cranberry juice labels around 1968. The Harpoon, as they called it, didn't call for Cointreau or triple sec though, and would have yielded a very bitter cocktail indeed. The Cosmo as we know it became popular in gay culture during the 70s and 80s and was picked up by a bartender at the Odeon in Manhattan in 1987. The Odeon was a well-known celebrity watering hole and was frequented by a number of stars. The Cosmo then made its way to the Rainbow Room, where Madonna famously posed with one. When HBO began featuring the cocktail on Sex and the City, mainstream culture latched on, and the rest, as they say, is history.

name: Cranberry Spiced Champagne
instructions:
Muddle 6 cranberries with lemon juice, agave nectar, and pumpkin
pie spice in mixing glass. Add sparkling wine or Champagne and ice
and gently fold. Strain into chilled champagne flute. Top with extra
splash of sparkling wine or Champagne. Float 3 cranberries on top.

name: Dark'n Stormy
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: George Bowman's Small Batch Dark rum is an excellent choice for the Dark & Stormy. It's subtle aroma of coconut and vanilla are followed by the rich flavors of molasses, honey and brown sugar, that are a perfect pair for the spicy ginger beer and touch of lime.
instructions:
Pour ginger beer into an ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Float rum on
top.
notes: Only a handful of the cocktail recipes out there are trademarked. The Dark ‘n' Stormy is one of them. The Gosling family, who owns the rights to this recipe, began dabbling in rum in Bermuda in the 1860s. Their experimentation resulted in a distinctly rich, dark rum that they would eventually christen “Gosling's Black Seal”. Around the same time, British sailors began brewing beer on the island using ginger root, which was said to cure seasickness. Eventually, someone had the grand idea to mix the two together, and the Dark ‘n' Stormy was born. The name is said to come from a sailor who said that it was “the color of a cloud only a fool or a dead man would sail under.” Fool or not, you're bound to enjoy this cocktail. Just be sure to use Gosling's Black Seal, or you may get a call from Mr. Gosling himself.

name: Devil's Soul
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into cocktail glass. Flame orange twist and add to glass.

name: Diablo
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The vanilla and cinnamon flavors in Corazon Reposado were made to pair with ginger beer,  they will enhance the the ginger and fold the flavor of the creme de cassis into the drink.
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled Collins
glass. Top with ginger ale. Garnish with lime.
notes: Many people never think about drinking tequila unless it's in a margarita or a shot glass. This drink is a perfect example of how the use of tequila can extend far beyond just that. The El Diablo is generally credited to the legendary Californian restaurateur Victor Bergeron, better known as “Trader Vic”, who seems to have concocted it sometime in the 1940s. The reasoning behind the name, which means the devil, is unclear. Perhaps it is a reference to its vivid red color or to the spicy notes imparted by the ginger beer. Crème de cassis, which is made from blackcurrants helps soften the ginger beer's bite and round out the flavor, and both harmonize well with the tequila. The balance of bright flavors in this drink makes it a great way to introduce someone to tequila without using sour mix or a salted rim.

name: Diva Quaranta
instructions:
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into chilled cocktail
glass. Top with Campari. Add orange twist.

name: Earl Grey Mar-Tea-Ni
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Shake remaining
ingredients without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into glass.
Grate lemon zest on top and add lemon twist.
notes:
Earl Grey Gin:  Shake 1 Tbs. loose-leaf Earl Grey tea with 8 oz. gin in jar and let
stand 2 hours. Stir and strain.

name: El Niño
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The white pepper and fresh mint flavors of Monte Alban Silver are a excellent match for the fresh strawberry and lime in the El Nino. They will add depth of flavor, and a layer of interest to this refreshing fruit forward cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle lime, strawberry, and syrup in mixing glass. Add tequila and
rose water and ice. Shake briefly and strain into ice-filled oldfashioned
glass.
notes: There is an endless number of variations on the El Niño. So many that some of them don't even resemble each other in the slightest. This recipe, which is simply tequila, muddled fruit, and simple syrup is sure to make a sweet and tangy treat on a hot summer's day.  Always opt for high-quality ingredients with recipes this simple. When so few ingredients are involved, each one can have a dramatic impact on the flavor of the cocktail. If strawberries aren't in season, you can try playing around with different combinations of fruit. Just remember that citrus of some sort is important for balancing out the tequila. Happy muddling!

name: Flower Power
instructions:
Shake without ice. Then shake with ice and strain into chilled
cocktail glass.

name: Garnet
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Garnet cocktail is a rich fruit forward cocktail that calls for a gin that can stand up to the sweetness of the pomegranate juice. Fleischmann's gin has a traditional botanical blend of a London Dry style, which gives it the body to support and shine in this sweet cocktail. It's aromatics of spice and pine will also pair nicely with the grapefruit juice giving the cocktail depth and interest.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Flame orange
twist and add.
notes: Once upon a time, gin was the clear spirit of choice amongst Americans. After Prohibition, our palates drifted toward less complex flavor profiles, and vodka took the place of gin on the American market. In the decades that followed, gin-distillers would attempt to win back their clientele by replacing the heavy spice and juniper notes of classic, London-style dry gin with lighter citrusy notes that would have more appeal on this side of the Atlantic. The Garnet is a cocktail that really cashes in on this brighter flavor profile by pairing it with the tang of pomegranate and grapefruit. Since this cocktail plays on the absence of that Christmas tree spice so often attributed to gin, this cocktail is an excellent choice for anyone looking to cross over from vodka cocktails to something a little more complex.

name: Georgia Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will only enhance the refreshing qualities of a Georgia Mule.  While it's buttery texture will cut the sharp qualities of the lime, and sweetness of the muddled peaches to create a balanced summer cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle 1 peach slice in Collins glass. Add vodka, lemon juice, and
bitters, then stir. Fill with ice and ginger beer; stir again. Garnish
with peach slice.
notes: It seems like everyone has their own mule these days, and why shouldn't they? After all, what doesn't go well with vodka and citrus? The Moscow Mule was invented in the 1940s, and people have been putting their own spin on it ever since. If you've ever been to the great state of Georgia, you know that people there are proud as punch of their peaches. It's even the official state fruit. (With any luck, one day the Georgia Mule will be the official state cocktail.) Now, most Georgians will probably tell you that there's nothing better than a bowl of homemade peach ice cream on a humid summer day, but the Georgia Mule is just as tasty. Besides who ever heard of getting a buzz off a bowl of ice cream?

name: Gibson (Gin)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The fewer ingredients in a cocktail recipe the more important the quality and flavor of the ingredients become. Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin is an superior choice for the Gibson with its amazingly light and smooth taste. Handcrafted with great care to create a fresh aromatic flavor that compliments the vermouth and makes for delicious easy drinking.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add onion.
notes: When the drink is comprised of spirits alone, stir the ingredients so they remain clear and unclouded by shaking. A barspoon's curves help rotate the spoon during stirring, and the spoon bowl guides poured liqueurs into position for layered drinks.

name: Gimlet (Gin)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The rich lime flavor in the Gimlet is perfeclty matched with the bright lemon flavors of Fleischmann's gin, making it, along with its spicy juniper aromas a perfect choice of gin when making this classic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes:
If desired, substitute 1 oz. Rose's Sweetened Lime Juice for the fresh lime juice and
simple syrup.

name: Grape Nehi
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Greyhound (Gin)
instructions: Pour into ice-filled highball glass. Stir well.

name: Grounds For Divorce
instructions: Stir and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Hemingway Daiquiri
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso White Rum in an excellent choice for the Hemingway Daiquiri with is light body and sweet cane sugar flavor. The sugar pairs nicely with the fruit juices, and allows the Maraschino to shine without drying out the cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled cocktail glass.
notes: There are many variations on the story of how the Hemingway Daiquiri came to be, but the general consensus is that the story begins with a bathroom break. While passing by El Floridita, a popular bar in Havana, Mr. Hemingway stopped off to answer nature's call and make use of the facilities. On the way out, he noticed the bartender preparing a large batch of Daiquiris and, not wanting to miss out on an opportunity, decided to try one. He told the bartender that he preferred his Daiquiris with no sugar and twice the normal dose of rum. The bartender made one as requested and named it after him. After the double dose of rum, the story gets a little fuzzy. Perhaps the bartender wasn't quite satisfied with the drink and decided to doctor it up with Maraschino and grapefruit juice. However it happened, this is an exceptional cocktail.

name: High Plains Drifter No. 1
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Swirl Campari in chilled cocktail glass to coat inside; discard
excess Campari. Shake remaining ingredients with ice and strain
into glass.

name: Hummingbird Down
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add mint leaf.

name: Juniper Breeze No. 1
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Fleischmann's Gin is an excellent choice for the Juniper Breeze No. 1. Its candied lemon and sweet juniper aromas enhance the tart fruit flavors, while its spicy peppery finish cut the rich sweetness of the elderflower cordial, creating a balanced cocktail.
instructions: Roll with ice in shaker. Pour into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.
notes: Imagine a perfect summer's day. Maybe you're sitting in a porch swing, maybe you're lying on a beach under an umbrella. A light afternoon breeze flutters gently by. You take a deep breath and bask in the glory of it all, and then you think to yourself, “I could really use a cocktail.” This is exactly what you need. The combination of gin and elderflower makes the Juniper Breeze #1 the perfect cocktail for lazy summer afternoons. It was created by one Ms. Julie Reiner, who has become somewhat of a fixture in the New York cocktail scene over the past 15 years. She has worked with a number of New York's finest establishments and is a co-owner of the Flatiron Lounge, where she says that this drink is very popular with her guests.

name: Last Word
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Last Word cocktail is a Prohibition era cocktail, complex, herbal, and tangy. Fleischmann's gin is a great choice of gin with it's interesting botanicals, rich in coriander, pine, and spice. These flavors pair nicely with the extremely herbal Green Chartreuse, creating a beautifully green, surprisingly balanced, classic cocktail.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: A cocktail with a simple recipe, yet such a complex array of flavors is bound to win any argument. The Last Word was originally created at the Detroit Athletic Club sometime in the 1920s. Many people attribute this cocktail's name to Frank Fogarty, a popular vaudevillian monologist who brought it to New York, where Ted Saucier discovered it and published it in his cocktail book Bottoms Up! in 1951. After World War Two, the Last Word fell into obscurity until it was revived by Murray Stenson in 2004. Stenson, who was looking for a new cocktail to serve in the Zig Zag Café in Seattle, achieved great success with his findings. The Last Word went on to inspire several well-known spin-off cocktails and spread to bars around the world. Its vivid color and flavor profile are certainly hard to beat.

name: Lemon Crush
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Shake ingredients
with ice and strain into glass.

name: Lemon Drop Shot
instructions:
Stir vodka with ice. Strain into chilled shot glass. Dip lemon wedge
in sugar. Shoot the vodka and immediately take a draw on the lemon.

name: Lights On The Plaza
instructions:
Muddle cucumbers, lemon juice, and syrup in mixing glass. Add
vodka, raspberry liqueur, and ice and shake. Double-strain into
chilled cocktail glass. Top with sparkling wine. Garnish with
raspberry-cucumber skewer.

name: Maracuya Mosquito
instructions:
Muddle 4 basil leaves in mixing glass. Add remaining ingredients.
Shake with ice. Double-strain through wire sieve into crushed ice-
filled Collins glass. Garnish with a basil leaf.

name: Martini (Perfect)
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist
or olive.

name: Melon Stand
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: This muddled watermelon cocktail is best showcased with a bright, citrus forward, dry gin to pair with the sweet watermelon and tart lemon juice. This cocktail can be manipulated to be more herbal with the use of an intensely botanical gin, but Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin is a great start for a well balanced, refreshing summer cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle melon chunks in mixing glass. Add remaining ingredients.
Shake with ice and strain into Collins glass filled with crushed ice. Garnish with watermelon.
notes: Nothing says summer quite like melon. From cantaloupe to honeydew to watermelon, there is just something about biting into a sweet slice of the stuff that will melt you like the summer sun. So what better way to celebrate summer than with a Melon Stand? It's the perfect cocktail to sip on the back porch on a hot day. And if you like Melon Balls, but want to try something a little more sophisticated, this is a great place to start. Melon imparts its sweet juicy flavor, but Aperol helps cut the sugariness, and gin provides that herbaceous backdrop that no other spirit can. The Melon Stand is perfect as a pre-cookout apéritif and is a great way to add a little flavor to your Fourth of July party.

name: Mexican Firing Squad
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
The Mexican Firing Squad is a sweet and spicy cocktail with fresh fruit juice paired with spicy Angostura bitters. Monte Alban Silver is a great choice for this cocktail with its creamy honey and vanilla flavor, and spicy finish that are a perfect compliment to the flavors of the Mexican Firing Squad.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters in this cocktail, in lieu of Angostura bitters.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake and strain into ice-filled highball glass. Garnish with lime.
notes: This cocktail's name suggests that it might be deadly, but it's actually pretty light. It tastes similar to a Margarita, but it's not quite as boozy and gets a bit of added depth from the pomegranate molasses and bitters. Pomegranate molasses can be a bit tricky to find, but it's fairly easy to make at home. Just reduce some pomegranate juice with a bit of sugar and lemon juice, and you'll be all set. The Mexican Firing Squad's earliest mention is in Charles H. Baker Jr.'s The Gentleman's Companion, Volume II, published in 1946. In it, the vagabond bon vivant tells a story about wandering from bar to bar in Mexico City in 1937 and finally discovering this cocktail at a bar called La Cucaracha. Another great summer cocktail, the Mexican Firing Squad is perfect for warm weather and light enough that you can enjoy more than just one.

name: Mojito
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The mojito is a refreshingly sweet long cocktail that is often served with a sugar cane stick. Calypso white rum with its mixture of vanilla and spice and buttery vanilla and cane sugar finish make it an excellent rum choice for this cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle the limes, mint, and syrup in a Collins glass. Add the rum
with ice and stir well. Top with soda water. Garnish with mint.
notes: It's amazing how much of cocktail history takes place in Cuba. Then again, thanks to the dark days of Prohibition, American cocktail-enthusiasts have a very special relationship with Cuba. Not so long ago, Cuban rum was barely palatable. Even Cubans themselves had to find ways to mask its noxious funk in order to drink it. Farmers would take whatever they had on hand to make their rum go down more easily, and often what they had on hand were the ingredients to what we now know as the Mojito. As Prohibition spread across America, Havana became our favorite offshore bar. The drinks of the Cuban working class made their way to the capital and into the hands of thirsty American tourists who would later recreate them at home. It's a well-know fact that bartenders today have a love-hate relationship with the Mojito, but it remains, nevertheless, an undeniable classic.

name: Monkey Gland
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Sunset Hills Small Batch Gin's bright citrus aromas enhance the bitter orange of the Campari, while its rich herbal botanicals bond perfectly with the herbal qualities of the sweet vermouth, producing a bittersweet classic Italian cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange
twist.
notes: Appreciating the name of this cocktail takes a bit of a dark sense of humor. It is credited to Harry MacElhone, who owned the famous Harry's New York Bar in Paris. MacElhone named this drink for medical experiments carried out by a Russian doctor named Serge Voronoff. It seems that Voronoff, who was seeking a medical method of rejuvenation performed several experiments in which he grafted tissue from the naughty bits of monkeys onto humans. Whether or not his work was successful, this cocktail is certain to revitalize. The use of real grenadine will really pop against the backdrop created by the orange juice, and will help highlight the sweeter notes of the gin. If you're up for a bit of experimentation yourself, try adding a dash of absinthe. Even a few drops can add a whole new dimension to this cocktail.

name: Mulled Wine
instructions:
Heat wine and spices in metal latte jug with steamer spout of
espresso machine. (Or heat in a small saucepan over very low heat
just until steaming.) Pour into preheated Irish coffee glass or mug.
Add rum and honey and stir. Garnish with lemon.
notes: The steamer spout of an espresso machine does a great job of heating the wine with the spices. If you don't have one, be careful not to let the rum and spice come to a boil. Make it in quantity for a large group.

name: Paddington
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Calypso White Rum's sweet sugar cane flavor is a great compliment to the tart grapefruit and sweet orange marmalade, while its light body produces a delicately sweet and fresh cocktail.
instructions:
Pour absinthe into chilled cocktail glass, swirl to coat inside, and
discard excess. Shake remaining ingredients with ice and strain into
glass. Add grapefruit twist.
notes: If alcoholic beverages could be adorable, this one definitely would be. You may be familiar with Paddington Bear, a beloved character in English children's literature. Paddington Bear hails from Peru and loves orange marmalade and his red Wellington boots. When mixologist David Hamilton Boyd was given the challenge of creating a cocktail inspired by a children's book character, he turned to Paddington. The original recipe was served over crushed ice in a glasses slotted into a small, red Wellington boot and garnished with tiny orange marmalade sandwiches. To give it a little extra Paddington flare, he called it “Does a Bear Drink Rum in Peru? (Of Course He Does)”. For the sake of brevity, we'll just call it a Paddington. And don't worry. If you're all out of small, red Wellingtons and tiny marmalade sandwiches, you can strain it into a cocktail glass and serve it with a grapefruit twist.

name: Paloma
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The subtle cooked agave qualities of Siete Leguas Blanco provides a wonderful foundation for this bright refreshing drink.
instructions:
Pour tequila into ice-filled Collins glass. Fill glass with soda and
stir briefly. Garnish with lime wedge.
notes: Now this is a drink that will wake up your taste buds. Grapefruit soda gives just enough sweetness while lime gives it a sour kick. Throw in a little salt and some tequila, and what more could you ask for? Soda also imparts a fizzy quality that makes any drink ten times more refreshing. If southern Mexico made champagne, it would probably taste something like this. In a pinch, grapefruit juice, soda water, and simple syrup can be substituted for grapefruit soda, but it will yield a heavier drink, so try to opt for the former. Some people like a salted rim; others prefer to throw a little salt straight into the drink. Either is fine, just don't omit it.

name: Pegu Club
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Fleischmann's Gin is an excellent choice for the Pegu Club, with its bright lemon and spicy juniper aromas that pair perfectly with the orange curacao to create a elegant and refreshing classic cocktail.

Consider Peychaud’s Bitters an excellent replacement for Angostura bitters in this cocktail. The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.
notes: The Pegu Club cocktail originated the Pegu Club in Rangoon, the capital of Myanmar or Burma, which was formerly part of the British Empire. The Pegu Club, named for the nearby Pegu River, made its way around the world with Brits and foreigners alike in the early 20th century. No one is certain who created it or when it was invented, but it must have been before 1927, as that was the year of publication of Harry MacElhone's Barflies and Cocktails, which was the first book to make mention of the Pegu Club. From there it became a mainstay in bar culture and a clear cultural reference.

name: Penicillin
instructions:
Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into ice-filled oldfashioned
glass. Float smoky Scotch on top and garnish with lemon.

name: Pimm's Cup
instructions:
Pour Pimm's into ice-filled Collins glass. Top with chilled ginger
ale. Garnish with cucumbers and/or lemon.
notes: The Pimm's Cup is an interesting link between the cities of London and New Orleans. Many New Orleanians seem to believe that the Pimm's Cup is native to their city, but it was actually brought there by the Napoleon House, a restaurant in the French Quarter. When the Napoleon House began serving Pimm's Cups, it was in an effort to prevent their clientele from completely inebriating themselves in the sweltering Louisiana summer heat. The Pimm's Cup originated in London though, where it is still drunk by the gallon in the summer. Pubs sell them by the pitcher, and at Wimbledon, over 40,000 pints of the stuff are sold within just two weeks. No one is quite sure how this cocktail made it across the Atlantic or which city drinks more of it. Whatever the case may be, the Pimm's Cup is just one more thing London and New Orleans have in common.

name: Pink Pussycat
instructions: Pour ingredients into ice-filled highball glass and stir.

name: Pisco Punch
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass.
notes:
The drink of the Gold Rush in San Francisco, as the most readily
available brandy was Peruvian. This is an adaptation of the original,
invented at The Bank Exchange bar.

name: Pisco Sour
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
Campo de Encanto Piscos are right at home on this traditional egg white sour, and with the brand's wide variety of Piscos the flavor of your Pisco sour is limitless.  Each label can bring a new subtle nuance to this cocktail.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters as a replacement for the Angostura bitters in this cocktail.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Strain into chilled
champagne flute or cocktail glass. Top with bitters.
notes: Americans have a fear of egg whites in their cocktails. It's completely irrational, but we understand. The Pisco Sour is the perfect example of a cocktail that can be bolstered by the use of egg white. Without it, this cocktail is thin on the palate and almost astringent. With it, it's almost like key lime pie in drink form. Both Chile and Peru claim to have invented the Pisco Sour, though each has a slightly different variation. The Peruvian version is a bit more complex and has some added depth, so we'll stick with it. Many recipes actually call for Peruvian key lime juice, so if you're looking for a really authentic version, try to find some. Beware of recipes that call for lemon juice though, as this is likely a translation error from the Spanish word limón.

name: Prohibition Punch
instructions:
Shake first five ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled snifter.
Top with Champagne.

name: Rio Fix
instructions:
Pour pastis into chilled champagne flute and swirl to coat inside.
Shake remaining ingredients with ice and strain into glass.

name: San Martin Cocktail
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Sidecar
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Meukow's rich aromas of baked spices and fruit combined with its round medium body are the perfect pairing for the classic Sidecar. It's dry-yet fruity flavor bond with the sweet citrus to create a deliciously balanced cocktail with a warm spicy finish.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
notes: Supposedly the Sidecar originated at the Ritz Hotel in Paris sometime in the early 20th century. Recipes began appearing in multiple publications in the year 1922. Widely considered to be one of the best cocktails of all time, the Sidecar is a very delicate balance of sweet and sour against the earthy backdrop that brandy provides. Recently, some bartenders have even begun making Bourbon Sidecars by substituting bourbon for the brandy. There are generally two different schools of thought when it comes to proportions in the Sidecar. The French school leans toward all three parts in equal amounts, while the English school calls for twice the amount of brandy. Both are fine, but the former tends to hide a lot of the brandy's flavor nuances. Therefore, we'll stick with the Brits on this one.

name: Strawberry Mimosa
instructions:
Process strawberries and orange juice in blender until smooth. Pour
into ice-filled hurricane glass. Fill with Champagne. Garnish with
orange and strawberry.

name: Summertime Breeze
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into Collins glasses. Garnish with pineapple and strawberries.

name: The Blinker
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: Thomas Handy Rye has such bold flavors of apricot, vanilla, and spice that pair perfectly with the raspberry syrup in the Blinker. It's dense aromas, and full body allows it to shine in this fruit forward sour.
instructions:
Shake and strain into cocktail glass. Garnish with grapefruit twist or
raspberry.
notes:
The original recipe, published in 1934, used grenadine, but the raspberry
syrup complements the grapefruit better. In this recipe, a thick ice-cream
topping syrup is preferable to the thin beverage flavoring syrup.

name: The Lemony Snicket Cocktail
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
the cherry.

name: The Moneypenny
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The Moneypenny's fresh grapefruit juice is best paired with a bright citrus forward London Dry gin with fresh herbal aromatics. Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin with its notes of cucumber and rose, paired with a light body make it an excellent choice for the Moneypenny cocktail.
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon and sugar. Shake remaining
ingredients with ice and strain into glass. Add grapefruit twist.
notes: Background information on the Moneypenny cocktail is even more elusive than background information on Miss Moneypenny herself. It's creation remains an enigma. Miss Moneypenny, a 007 character, is the secretary of M, the head of MI6 throughout much of the James Bond saga. She shares a very flirtatious relationship with Mr. Bond, but she never pursues him as she is too much of a lady. This is a tart cocktail, to say the least. The combination of grapefruit and lemon yields a rather acidic mixture, while gin and Lillet Blanc add drier floral notes. The raw sugar rim pulls everything together and saves the day. To put it into Bond terms, this cocktail is “shocking—positively shocking.”

name: The Normandy
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
apple slice.

name: Traditional Martini (Dry)
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: It's hand crafted, and small batch quality, paired with its bright citrus flavor and rich botanical aromatics make Sunset Hill's Small Batch gin an excellent choice for the ultimate gin classic; the Martini.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.
notes:
From this we can see that the Martini, containing just gin, sweet
vermouth, and bitters, was really a gin version of the Manhattan. And like
the Manhattan, when ordered normally it would be made with sweet
vermouth, and when ordered "dry" with dry (French) vermouth.

name: Vesper
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The clean crisp flavors of Rain vodka will enhance the bright citrus qualities of the gin and Lillet creating a delicately smooth cocktail.
instructions:
Shake with ice. Strain into chilled Champagne or cocktail glass. Add
lemon twist.
notes: Even if you haven't read a single James bond novel, you're bound to recognize this drink by name—though you may not know what's in it. Bond is infamous for his drinking habits, and indulges in everything from Dom Pérignon to Heineken. This tasty tipple is a sort of dressed up martini. When 007 specifies the contents of the Vesper in Casino Royale, he asks the bartender to use Kina Lillet, an apéritif wine from the Bordeaux region of France. Kina Lillet is no longer manufactured as the company altered its recipe in 1986 to create Lillet Blanc, a similar but less bitter version of their previous product. Many cocktail experts will suggest Cocchi Americano as the closest cousin to Kina Lillet, so use whichever you prefer. Why Mr. Bond prefers his Vesper shaken is a bit of a mystery. We recommend stirring to prevent clouding and over-dilution.

name: Vieux Carre
ingredient_replacement_suggestions:
This New Orleans cocktail is fun, potent, and complex which makes Sazerac rye, with its romas of clove, vanilla, and anise, combined with its subtle notes of candies spices and citrus an excellent choice for the Vieux Carre.

Also consider Peychaud’s Bitters as a replacement for the Angostura bitters in this cocktail.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Pour into ice-filled old-fashioned glass and stir.
notes: The Vieux Carré is a slow-sipper. It's not a drink that you try to down in two minutes. No, this is a drink that needs to be relished, savored—a cocktail that almost slows down the passage of time. The name of this drink comes from a French nickname for the French Quarter in New Orleans meaning “old square”. It was invented at the city's famed Carousel Bar, and like the Big Easy itself, blends together diverse elements with strong characters to create something great. The use of Bénédictine and two different types of bitters lends this cocktail a multi-dimensional flavor that is fantastic in its complexity. If you're in New Orleans, be sure to stop by the birthplace of the Vieux Carré to enjoy one on the revolving Carousel Bar.

name: Water Lily
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange
twist.

ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake well with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with cherry.
Shake first three ingredients with ice and strain into ice-filled Collins glass. Top with ginger ale. Garnish with lemon and lime.

name: 19th Century
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: A Currant Affair
instructions: Shake with ice and strain through wire sieve into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with lemon and currants.

name: Academic Review
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Add orange twist.

name: Accoutrement
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add cherry.

name: Adderly Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into cocktail glass. Flame orange twist and add.

name: Admiral Perry
instructions:
Stir with ice and shake into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with pear
slice.

name: Affinity Cocktail (whisky)
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Agricole Rum Punch
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled Collins glass. Top with
nutmeg.

name: Akogare
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Alabazam
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Flame orange twist and add.

name: Almond Tea Toddy
instructions: Stir in preheated Irish coffee glass or mug. Garnish with orange.

name: American Trilogy
instructions: Muddle sugar cube in mixer glass. Add whiskey, applejack, and ice. Stir and strain into chilled old-fashioned glass. Add orange twist.

name: Ancient Mariner
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into old-fashioned glass filled with crushed ice. Garnish with lime and mint.

name: Angel's Share
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Apple Pie
instructions:
Pour into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish with apple and top
with cinnamon.

name: Apple River Inner Tuber
instructions:
Process ingredients with 1 cup crushed ice in blender until smooth.
Pour into hurricane glass. Garnish with spiced apple.

name: Apple-Cinnamon Soda
instructions: Pour into ice-filled pilsner glass and stir briefly. Garnish with apple.

name: Apple-Cinnaom Sparkler
instructions:
Gently fold ingredients with ice in mixing glass. Strain into chilled
champagne flute. Top with extra splash of sparkling wine or
Champagne. Add apple.

name: Apricot Brandy Eggnog
instructions: Combine ingredients in large punch bowl. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Archangel
instructions:
Muddle cucumber in mixing glass. Add gin and Aperol with ice, stir,
and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Astoria Bianco
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Audrey Fanning
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Autumn Leaves
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Add
orange twist.

name: Aztec's Mark
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Back Porch Swizzle
instructions:
Pour first four ingredients in crushed ice-filled highball glass. With
barspoon between your palms, move hands back and forth and up
and down to quickly rotate and lift spoon, until glass is frosted.
Float Chartreuse on top, and garnish with mint.

name: Bad-Humored Old-Fashioned
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled old-fashioned glass. Add lemon
twist.

name: Bajito
instructions:
Muddle mint, 4 basil leaves, and lime with syrup in mixing glass.
Add ice and rum. Shake well and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned
glass. Garnish with basil leaf.

name: Banana Bomber
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled shot glass.

name: Banana Frozen Daiquiri
instructions:
Process ingredients in blender with 1 cup crushed ice until smooth.
Pour into champagne flute. Garnish with cherry.

name: Basil 8
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Muddle basil and 5 grapes in Collins glass. Add next four
ingredients and stir. Add ice and top with ginger ale. Garnish with
basil sprig and 1 white grape.

name: Basil's Bite
instructions:
Muddle basil leaves in mixing glass. Shake with remaining
ingredients and ice. Strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
basil leaf.

name: Bee Sting
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
star anise.

name: Bee's Kiss
instructions: Shake and strain into a chilled champagne flute.

name: Bella Fragolia
instructions:
Muddle chopped strawberry and 4 basil leaves in mixing glass. Add
vodka, lemon juice, and syrup with ice and shake well. Double-strain
into ice-filled old-fashioned glass and top with soda water. Garnish
with strawberry and basil.

name: Bella Rosa
instructions:
Shake first five ingredients with ice, shaking hard to break up
strawberry. Strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Top with
ginger beer.

name: Benjamin Barker Daiquiri
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with
lime wedge.

name: Bensonhurst
instructions:
Swirl Cynar in chilled cocktail glass to coat inside; discard excess
Cynar. Stir remaining ingredients with ice and strain into glass.

name: Berliner
instructions:
Mix sugar and caraway seed. Rim chilled cocktail glass with lemon
and sugar mixture. Shake next four ingredients with ice and pour
into glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Bermuda Rum Swizzle
instructions:
Combine first five ingredients in ice-filled Collins glass. With
bar-spoon between your palms, move hands back and forth and up
and down to quickly rotate and lift spoon, until glass is frosted. Top
with soda water. Garnish with orange and cherry. Serve with a
swizzle stick.

name: Bianca
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with lime and sugar. Shake remaining
ingredients with ice and strain into glass. Add lemon twist and
pomegranate seeds.

name: Bistro Sidecar
instructions:
Rim chilled cocktail glass with tangerine and sugar. Shake
ingredients with ice. Strain into glass. Add hazelnut.

name: Bitches' Brew
instructions: Shake without ice. Shake with ice and strain into highball glass. Top with nutmeg.

name: Bitter Mai Tai
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into crushed ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish with mint.

name: Bitterly Dark
instructions: Shake and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with orange wheel.

name: Black Cat
instructions: Muddle grapefruit zest and syrup in mixing glass. Add other ingredients and stir with ice. Strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add grapefruit twist.

name: Black Cherry Chocolate
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Black Feather
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Stir and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Black Widow
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass.

name: Blackberry Fizz
instructions: Muddle blackberries, lemon juice, and syrup in mixing glass. Add Lillet, gin, and ice and shake. Strain into chilled champagne flute. Top with sparkling wine. Garnish with blackberry.

name: Blackberry Soda
instructions: Muddle blackberries with honey syrup and lemon juice in mixing glass. Add ice and shake. Strain into ice-filled pilsner glass. Top with ginger ale and stir briefly. Garnish with skewered blackberry and lemon.

name: Blood and Samba
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Flame orange
twist and add.

name: Blood Orange
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Bloody Scotsman
instructions:
Mix ingredients together, stirring often, in a large container, adding
salt to taste. Chill for at least 24 hours before serving. Serve in icefilled

notes:

notes:
Vanilla-Infused Bourbon:  Split 3 Tahitian vanilla beans lengthwise. Insert into 750-ml bottle
of bourbon. Close bottle and let stand at room temperature for 3 to 5 days. Remove vanilla beans. Store bourbon at room temperature for
up to 1 month.

Honey-Currant Syrup:   Bring 1 cup honey, ½ cup dried currants, and ¼ cup water to a simmer over medium heat in small saucepan, stirring to dissolve honey. Simmer over low heat for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Strain into jar, cover, and refrigerate for up to 3 weeks.

Buy some packaged cotton candy for this cocktail's garnish, or skip the candy and garnish with an edible flower.

name: Eggnog (Cooked)
instructions:
Heat half-and-half and sugar in medium saucepan over medium heat,
stirring to dissolve sugar. Whisk egg yolks in large heatproof bowl
until thickened; gradually whisk in hot mixture. Return to saucepan
and stir with wooden spoon over medium-low heat until custard
coats spoon and reads 185Â°F on instant-read thermometer. Strain
through wire sieve into preheated large punch bowl; let cool. Stir in
rum. Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at least 4 hours. Whip
cream to soft peaks and fold into custard. Serve in punch cups and
top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Gin Gin Mule
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: The spicy ginger flavor and bright mint aromatics are the true stars of the Gin Gin Mule. Fleischmann's Gin, with its spicy, pine aromatics and crisp citrus flavor perfectly showcase those ingredients, creating a refreshingly balanced cocktail.
instructions:
Muddle mint with syrup and lime juice in mixing glass. Add gin and
ice and shake well. Strain into ice-filled highball glass. Fill with
ginger beer.
notes: The Gin Gin Mule, like most cocktails, is a variation on a variation. Created by Pegu Club owner Audrey Saunders, this cocktail is about as refreshing as it gets and, honestly, just plain delicious. Ginger and whiskey have long been a popular combination in cocktail recipes, but gin makes for better summertime drinking. Gin's botanicals are a perfect compliment to ginger's spicy bite, and mint exponentially increases this drink's cooling power. The trickiest part to making a great Gin Gin Mule is finding the right kind of ginger beer—and no, ginger ale won't do. If you're using a sweeter ginger beer, you might want to cut back on the simple syrup, but the most important factor is the spice. Spicier ginger beer will help all the other flavors pop against each other. Think of it as an air-conditioned Fourth of July fireworks display for your taste buds.

name: Golden Eggnog
instructions:
Beat egg white with 1/2 tsp. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat yolk well
with remaining 1/2 tsp. sugar until pale and thickened. Add white and
gently fold together. Add liqueur and milk and mix gently. Pour into
ice-filled cocktail glass. Top with nutmeg and gold leaf.
notes:
Your guests will feel very special when presented with gold-topped cups of nog. To transfer the edible gold (or silver) leaf to the drink, use the tip of a fine-tipped artist's brush to lift a large flake of the gold from its tissue. Touch the edge of the flake onto the surface of the eggnog and
remove the paintbrush without getting the bristles wet.

name: Golden Eggnog (Large Batch)
instructions:
Beat egg whites with 1 Tbs. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat yolks
well with remaining 1 Tbs. sugar until pale and thickened. Add whites and gently fold together. Add liqueur and milk and mix gently. Pour into ice-filled cocktail glasses. Top each with nutmeg and gold leaf.

name: Honey-Currant Syrup
instructions: Bring 1 cup honey, 1/2 cup dried currants, and 1/4 cup water to a simmer over medium heat in small saucepan, stirring to dissolve honey. Simmer over low heat for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and let cool. Strain into jar, cover, and refrigerate for up to 3 weeks.

name: Old-Fashioned Eggnog
instructions:
In a large bowl, beat eggs until pale and foamy. Add sugar and salt, beating until thickened. Stir in rum, half-and-half, and milk. Chill at
least 3 hours. Serve in punch cups and top each serving with nutmeg.

name: Old-Fashioned Whiskey Cocktail
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Pour rye or bourbon, syrup, and bitters into a cracked-ice-filled old fashioned glass and stir. Add lemon twist.
notes: This Old-Fashioned reflects the way this cocktail should taste. Simple syrup is used because it's easier than muddling the sugar in the glass and also provides a more consistent sweetening. Unlike many modern renditions, there is no cherry or orange muddled in with the bitters and sweetener at the beginning and there is no soda or water at the end. The water melting from the ice is just the right amount to even out the rough edges of the whiskey.

bitters and nothing else except a cherry garnish.

name: Saratoga Cocktail (Johnson Version)

Peach Tea-Infused Gin:  Pour 1 cup gin into bowl. Add 1 peach tea bag. Let stand for 20 minutes. Strain into another bowl, pressing hard on tea bag. Funnel into covered jar, pressing hard on peach bag. Store, refrigerated, for
up to 3 weeks.

name: The World Bar Eggnog
instructions:
Beat egg white with 1 tsp. sugar until soft peaks form. Beat egg yolk
well until pale and thick. Add white and gently fold together. Beat cream, almond, and vanilla extracts with remaining 1 tsp. sugar until stiff. Add to egg mixture and gently fold together. Fold in rum. Pour into ice-filled punch cup or cocktail glass. Top with cinnamon
and nutmeg.

name: The World Bar Eggnog (Large Batch)
instructions:
Beat egg whites with 1/2 cup sugar until soft peaks form. Beat egg
yolks well until pale and thickened. Add whites and gently fold together. Beat cream, almond and vanilla extracts, and remaining  1/2 cup sugar until soft peaks form. Add to egg mixture and gradually
fold together. Fold in rum. Cover and refrigerate until chilled, at
least 4 hours or overnight. Pour into punch bowl and top with nutmeg and cinnamon. Serve, without ice, in punch cups or cocktail glasses.

name: Three Card Monty
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Thyme Collins
instructions:
Put first four ingredients in mixing glass, add ice, and shake well.
Strain into ice-filled Collins glass. Top with bitter lemon soda and
stir briefly. Garnish with long thyme sprigs.

name: Tia Juanathan
instructions:

name: Tom and Jerry (Creamy)
instructions:
To make batter, beat egg whites in large bowl to stiff peaks. Beat
yolks in medium bowl until thickened. Gradually beat in sugar until
very thick and pale yellow. Mix in brandy and rum. Fold in whites.
(If you have a Tom and Jerry serving bowl, transfer batter to bowl.)
Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve, up to 1 day.
For each serving, spoon batter into preheated punch cup or coffee
mug. Add milk to fill and stir. Top with nutmeg.
notes:
For 1 serving
1 oz. Tom and Jerry Batter
5 oz. hot milk, as needed
Garnish: Freshly grated nutmeg

name: Tom and Jerry for Two
instructions:
Beat egg white until soft peaks form. Beat egg yolk with sugar until
thick and pale yellow. Fold in white. Divide batter, brandy, and milk
between two preheated punch cups or coffee mugs and stir well. Top
with nutmeg.
notes:
Instead of the brandy, substitute light rum, or use a combination of
brandy and rum.

name: Tombstone
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon
twist.

name: Traditional Martini (Sweet)
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.
notes:
From this we can see that the Martini, containing just gin, sweet
vermouth, and bitters, was really a gin version of the Manhattan. And like the Manhattan, when ordered normally it would be made with sweet
vermouth, and when ordered "dry" with dry (French) vermouth.

name: Trident
instructions: Stir and strain into cocktail glass. Garnish with lemon twist.

name: Tridentt
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add lemon twist.

name: Twentieth-Century Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Underneath The Mango Tree
instructions:
Rim Collins glass with lime and sweet chili powder. Fill glass with
ice. Shake next four ingredients with ice. Strain into glass. Top with
ginger ale.

name: Union Cocktail
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Union Jack
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Urban Anxiety
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions:
Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Flame grapefruit
twist and add.

name: Vagabond
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: Vagabundo
instructions:
Shake ingredients with ice. Strain into ice-filled hurricane glass.
Garnish with lime wheel.
notes: You'll need fresh celery juice to make this cocktail.

name: Vanilla-Infused Bourbon
instructions: Split 3 Tahitian vanilla beans lengthwise. Insert into 750-ml bottle of bourbon. Close bottle and let stand at room temperature for 3 to 5 days. Remove vanilla beans. Store bourbon at room temperature for up to 1 month.

name: Venial Sin
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Verrazano
instructions:
Swirl Campari in chilled cocktail glass to coat inside; discard
excess Campari. Stir remaining ingredients with ice and strain into
glass. Add orange twist.

name: Vieux Mot
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Virginia Dare
ingredient_replacement_suggestions: World famous Peychaud’s Bitters were created by Antoine Amedie Peychaud in New Orleans in the early 1800s.  It is a proprietary recipe that includes several different herbs and spices.  The Peychaud’s flavor profile is a zesty blend of anise, nutmeg and clove notes with a slightly sweet, floral taste.
instructions: Muddle 1 pear slice in mixing glass. Add remaining ingredients. Shake with ice and strain through a fine wire sieve into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with remaining pear slice.

name: Vow Of Silence
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Waiting On Summer
instructions:
Muddle cucumber, sage, and lime juice in mixing glass. Add tequila
and syrup with ice and shake. Double-strain into ice-filled Collins
glass. Top with ginger ale. Garnish with strawberry.

name: Warm Winter Cider
instructions:
In large saucepan, bring cider and cinnamon to a full boil over
medium heat. Reduce heat and add rum, brandy, and schnapps,
stirring until heated through. Serve in punch cups garnished with
cinnamon sticks and apples.

name: Washington Apple
instructions: Pour into ice-filled highball glass and stir.

name: Weeski
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add orange twist.

name: West Side
instructions:
Shake first four ingredients with ice and double-strain into chilled
cocktail glass. Top with a splash of soda water.

name: White Spider
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: White Wine Cup
instructions:
Pour ingredients into large pitcher. Stir. Fill with ice. Garnish with
fruit. Insert cucumber peels inside pitcher and top with mint. Serve
in white-wine glasses.

name: Whoa, Nellie!
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add grapefruit
twist.

name: Wolf's Bite
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Woolworth
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass.

name: Yellow Jacket
instructions:
Shake with ice and strain into ice-filled old-fashioned glass. Garnish
with lemon.

name: Yellow Rose Of Texas
instructions:
Shake first four ingredients with ice and strain into chilled cocktail
glass. Top with rose water.

name: Yokahama Romance
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Add rose petal.

name: Zwackberry Flip
instructions:
Shake without ice. Add ice and shake again. Double-strain into
chilled cocktail glass. Top with chocolate.
